name: Ilse Harms
position 1: Senior advisor Human Factors & Vehicle Automation at RDW
position 2: Alternate Director for The Netherlands, Board of Directors Euro NCAP
skills: ['Road Safety', 'Human Factors', 'Dutch', 'Psychology', 'Experimental Design', 'Analysis', 'Research', 'Policy', 'Traffic Psychology', 'Government', 'Statistics', 'SPSS', 'Urban Planning']
summary:
--> --> N.B. My PhD is almost finished. I will defend my PhD thesis on 23 September 2021. You can find more info here: https://www.rug.nl/news/2021/09/in-traffic-we-see-more-than-we-think

About me: Enthusiastic traffic psychologist who bridges the gap between science and practice. I am particularly interested in human factors and vehicle automation, ranging from assisted driving (ADAS) to automated driving and autonomous driving. I work on topics such as human machine interaction (HMI) and vehicle driving skill. Since 2021 I have the pleasure to work at RDW, the Dutch Vehicle Authority, as the lead on human factors and vehicle automation and to work closely together with the experts of CBR.
Previously I combined my work at the Dutch government with PhD research in the field of traffic psychology. I combine knowledge with a broad (inter)national network of human factors and traffic experts to obtain results and push forwards the safe deployment of smart mobility.

My PhD research is about information along familiar routes: on what we perceive and how this affects human behaviour. I have a specific interest in the detection of driving-related information and changes in this information, specifically concerning traffic management. If you are interested in my PhD work, you can find more info here: https://twitter.com/ilseharms/status/1438861650795405314?s=20.

Additionally, I am
- Alternate Director for the Netherlands at Euro NCAP
- Chair of the board of De VerkeersGedragDag, the leading national conference for professionals within traffic psychology - from knowledge institutes, market parties and governments - where we yearly share the state of the art in our field of work (www.devgd.nl),  
- peer reviewer for the scientific journal Transportation Research Part F, 
- a writer of scientific articles,
- sharer of research results with the general public through the media, including the NOS news on TV, radio shows on e.g. Radio538 and BNR, and various newspapers,
- and a lecturer on the full extent of traffic psychology through guest lectures and master classes for organisations and institutes such as DTV, PAO, NHL and HAN. 
The most important thing of knowledge is that is shared and applied! 

#TrafficPsychology #HumanFactors #Behaviour #VehicleAutomation #RoadSafety #ITS #Consultancy #PhDlife

name: Jitske Kramer
skills: ['Culture Change', 'Intercultural Communication', 'Leadership Development', 'Coaching', 'Public Speaking', 'Training Skills', 'Team Building', 'Training', 'Change Management', 'Strategy', 'Management Development', 'Personal Development', 'Leadership', 'Management Consulting', 'Executive Coaching', 'Organizational Development', 'Teamwork', 'Workshop Facilitation', 'Management', 'Program Management']
summary:
Jitske Kramer travels all over the world to learn from traditional healers, leaders, surprising innovators and random passers-by. She looks at the world and at organizations through the eyes of an anthropologist. Cultural anthropology is the discipline that asks what it means to be a human among humans in organisations and beyond. In 2012 she put Lewis method of Deep Democracy on the map in the Netherlands and she now works with a team of instructors to provide Deep Democracy training courses. She is always looking for ways to build strong tribes and reinforce the relationships between people. And then she brings that knowledge back to the world of organizing, cooperation and leadership through challenging keynotes and master classes. To improve the strength and results of individuals and groups (and to make the world a more beautiful place). She trains people, so that we never have to have meetings again. She takes you along in narratives that create space for new ways of seeing and new ways of dealing. Gradually, what is familiar becomes strange. And what is strange becomes familiar.

Jitske Kramer. Corporate anthropologist. Keynote Speaker. Entrepreneur. Facilitator. Founder of Human Dimensions. 2013 Trainer of the Year. Author of Deep Democracy (NL), Wow! What a Difference, The Corporate Tribe (2016 Management Book of the Year), Building Tribes, Voodoo and Jam Cultures - about inclusion.

What others say about Jitske:
‚ÄúJitske Kramer is one of the best speakers of the Netherlands. She is energetic, sharp and connecting. She stimulates you to really think differently and to voice your thoughts and opinions. She talks with flair, humor and guts. Challenging the obvious. Asking questions. Seeking out for surprising new insights and practical applicability. Formal when needed, informal when possible. In short: Jitske rocks.‚Äù

name: Ieva Palubeckaite
skills: ['Molecular Biology', 'Mass Spectrometry', 'Research', 'Biochemistry', 'Microbiology', 'Protein Purification', 'Cell Biology', 'Protein Chemistry', 'MALDI-MS', 'LC-MS']
summary:
Mission statement:

"Provide tailored mass spectrometry imaging solutions for product development purposes, in order to better understand product function and highlight important pathways of action."

I established my start-up company, AKIN solutions, in order to pursue this goal.

Experience:

I successfully graduated my multidisciplinary PhD in 2018 which was focused on mass spectrometry imaging method development for analysis of advanced 3D cell culture models. Then I moved on to a role at the Leiden University Medical Center to establish tailored 3D cell culture and analytical protocols in order to address informational gaps in sarcoma research. This involved generation of patient-derived sarcoma models, the creation of suitable 3D cell culture methods within the group, and the adaptation of appropriate mass spectrometry imaging protocols for the analysis of these models. 

Funded by an EMBO fellowship I worked at the Center for Mass Spectrometry and Optical Spectroscopy (CeMOS) in Mannheim for four months (Jan-Apr 2022), in collaboration with the LUMC. Here, I developed chiral MSI protocols for oncometabolite imaging in rare cancer types. During the fellowship, I also consulted on relevant industrial and academic projects within the institute which is when I started a private consultancy for MSI and 3D cell culture applications.

Currently, I am also working as a post-doctoral researcher at the Center for Proteomics and Metabolomics on the development of advanced MALDI-based analytical protocols of biological isolates for industry partners.

Over Tim:
Als Startup ondernemer heeft Tim verschillende bedrijven opgericht.
Het bedrijf Prindustry is vandaag de dag een marktleider in web2print software en Digital Asset Management. Tim stond aan de wieg van de webshop functionaliteiten en maakte de verbinding met de eerste 100 klanten. 

Bardoggy is een platform voor de horeca. In de tijd van lancering waren er apps als MyOrder, Scoopy en IENS die (met name gericht op restaurants) de verbinding maakte tussen bezoeker en locatie. Er was geen dominante speler specifiek voor de cafe horeca en de uitgaanssector.
Met funding (in totaal ca. 1miljoen), en een team is de MVP gelanceerd en groeide BarDoggy uit tot een app met voordeel coupons bij populaire uitgaanslocaties. Producenten sloten zich aan en konden kwalitatieve introducties van nieuwe producten aanbieden of juist bestaande producten een boost geven. 

Op het hoogtepunt zijn er 500 horeca locaties actief op BarDoggy en worden er wekelijks tienduizenden drankjes met de app aangeschaft.De conservatieve en traditionele houding van de sector maakt dat het lastig is om de meerwaarde van de consumentendata te kapitaliseren waardoor na 5 jaar een concreet verdienmodel uitblijft. De technologie is verkocht en het platform is in 2020 uit de lucht gehaald.

In commerci√´le rollen bij Print.com (250 FTE) en Lytho (40 FTE) is Tim verantwoordelijk voor de groei. Als teamspeler zoekt hij  graag de verbinding met collega‚Äôs om samen tot een mooi resultaat te komen. Hij geeft leiding op een mensgerichte manier en heeft focus op een goeie teamdynamiek. 

De heeft Tim ruim 50 bedrijven begeleid als startup en business coach. Daarnaast is hij spreker en geeft hij workshops over business-modelling en ScalingUp. Op strategische vlak is Tim betrokken bij talentontwikkeling, schaalbaarheid van Novel-T en de langetermijnvisie / strategie.

summary:
Dr. Ksenia Podoynitsyna is an Associate Professor in Data-Driven Entrepreneurship at JADS, the Joint Graduate School of Tilburg University and Eindhoven University of Technology.
Ksenia‚Äôs dissertation (2008) was nominated for the prestigious Heizer dissertation award of the Entrepreneurship division of the Academy of Management. Ever since her research helps manage the risks and uncertainties surrounding new business development. Combining scientific rigor with practical relevance, Ksenia got funding for a number of research and teaching initiatives in the context of sustainable energy and data science, funded by the EU, EIT KIC InnoEnergy, and Philips among others.
  Her current focus is on business models and ecosystems for data-driven and sustainable businesses. Projects include implications of revenue model and feature innovations in the Apple app store, business model innovations in smart cities, and patterns in innovative sustainable business models. The latter project resulted in a tool for mapping the business model of a focal company together with its immediate ecosystem. This tool is distinctive for its focus on value exchanges between the focal firm and external actors, and the options for structuring both value creating and value capturing transfers.   Ksenia has published in journals such as Journal of Business Venturing, Entrepreneurship Theory and Practice, California Management Review, Journal of Product Innovation Management, and Strategic Organization. On top of this, she serves on the Research Committee of the Entrepreneurship Division of the Academy of Management.

name: Jean-Pierre Kempeneers
position 1: Acting head of the Embassy of the Kingdom of the Netherlands in Port of Spain
position 2: Senior Director Government Relations and European Affairs
field of studies 1: Law, International Public Law, European Law
field of studies 2: Politique ext√©rieure de la France, droit publique
skills: ['Foreign Policy, diplomacy, Europe, EU, UN, Human Rights, Trade Promotion.', 'Diplomacy', 'International Relations', 'Foreign Policy', 'Politics', 'European Union', 'Policy Analysis', 'Human Rights', 'Government', 'Public Policy', 'International Development', 'Public Administration', 'Dutch', 'Policy', 'Public Diplomacy', 'International Organizations', 'Etiquette', 'Coaching', 'Interpersonal Communication Abilities']
summary:
Jean-Pierre Kempeneers is acting head of the Dutch Embassy in Port of Spain in August 2023. He was acting deputy Head of the Embassy  in Warsaw from October 2022 until April 2023. He has been on special assignments at the Ministry of Foreign Affairs of the Netherlands since 22 August 2022. Before that he was Ambassador, National Coordinator International Positions at the Ministry of Foreign Affairs of the Netherlands since August 2016.

From early 2014 until summer 2016 he worked at Royal Philips as Senior Director Government Relations & European Affairs and Head of the Philips' European Office in Brussels.

Jean-Pierre is a frequent lecturer and moderator at student-/university events. Since March 2013 he has been lecturer, moderator, and co-designer of the Brussels module of Avicenna, Academy for Leadership. He has also co-designed training modules with (Z)LTO Academy for agri- and horticultural professionals.

He has been coach and mentor to various (young) professionals for more than 15 year.

Jean-Pierre has been a diplomat in the Dutch MFA since 1995. He worked in the Europe Department covering 29 European countries with his team. He was Human Rights chief in the Ministry and Deputy Director of Human Rights, Humanitarian Aid, Good Governance, and Emancipation.

From 2006-August 2010 he was Head of the Political Section of the Permanent Representation of the Netherlands to the United Nations in New York. He was also the spokesman of the Mission.

Before this he was the Chief of Cabinet of / Private Secretary to the Minister for European Affairs of the Netherlands from 2002-2006.

From 1995-2002 he dealt with EU enlargement in both the Dutch and Austrian MFA's, served at the Dutch Embassy in Vienna covering Austria and Slovenia and he was Head of the Economic and Trade section of the Dutch Embassy in Tel Aviv.

Before joining the MFA Jean-Pierre worked in the European Parliament as speechwriter to the President of the Liberals, Mr. Gijs de Vries.
In 1994 he was intern in the European Commission dealing with the Middle East.

He was participant in the Government wide leadership course of the Dutch Government from Jan 2012-Dec 2013.

In January 2010 he participated in the UN Senior Mission Leadership Course in Port Dickson, Malaysia. Jean-Pierre was rated best participant and top three participant of the last 11 courses (approx. 300 participants) by the mentors.

He is a lawyer by education. 

Jean-Pierre is an avid sportsman (running, cycling, soccer, skiing, skating, golf, tennis) and coaches a football team under 14 years and is often referee.

name: Philomena Bluyssen
skills: ['Sustainable Development', 'Sustainability', 'Indoor Air Quality', 'Research', 'Science', 'Environmental Awareness', 'European Union', 'Construction', 'Green Building', 'Dutch', 'Program Management', 'Project Planning', 'Energy', 'Simulations', 'Policy', 'Innovation Management', 'Energy Efficiency', 'Statistics', 'Project Management', 'Analysis']
summary:
Prof. dr. Philomena Bluyssen received her building engineering degree in 1986 from the Technical University in Eindhoven, the Netherlands. From 1987 to 1990 she performed her PhD at the Technical University of Denmark under supervision of Prof. Fanger. And in 1998 she received her MBA degree at the University of Rotterdam. From 1991 to 2012 she worked with TNO. From October 1, 2012 she started as a full professor of Indoor environment at the Delft University of Technology. She is member of ASHRAE, ISIAQ, and CIB, and she has (co)authored more than 285 publications on national and international conferences and journals. She wrote the Indoor Environment Handbook for which she received the Choice Outstanding Academic Title Award 2010. In 2014 the Healthy Indoor Environment - How to assess occupants wellbeing was released, that won the IDEC 2016 book award. In 2015 she published: 
"Wat je moet weten over binnenlucht ‚ÄìEen eenvoudige gids om jezelf te leren je binnenmilieu te verbeteren" http://www.delftacademicpress.nl/b026.php
"All you need to know about indoor air ‚Äì A simple guide for educating yourself to improve your indoor environment" http://www.delftacademicpress.nl/b027.php
Some past positions:
- 1992-1995 Coordinator of the first European project in the area of indoor air quality: "European audit project to optimize indoor air quality and energy consumption in office buildings"
- 2000‚Äì2004 President of the Dutch chapter of ISIAQ
- 2001‚Äì2003 Knowledge transfer manager of the Centre of Building and Systems, a cooperation between the Technical University of Eindhoven and TNO
- 2002‚Äì2003 Deputy department leader and Business developer
- 2002‚Äì2006 Coordinator knowledge theme ‚ÄúHealth, comfort and energy‚Äù 
- 2006-2008 Dutch representative for CEN TC 351 on emissions of dangerous substances from Construction products
- 2007- 2010 Coordinator of HealthyAir project sponsored by DG Sanco.
Senselab was opened at December 1, 2016 in the Science Centre of the TU Delft!

name: Menno van Pelt-Deen
skills: ['Social Impact Games', 'Design', 'User Research', 'Mental Health', 'Public Health', 'Public Speaking', 'Game Theory', 'Game Design', 'Research', 'New Media', 'Video Games', 'Motivation', 'Serious Games', 'play', '3D', 'Game Development', 'Human Computer Interaction', 'Graphic Design', 'Mobile Devices', 'Interaction Design']
summary:
Dr. Menno van Pelt-Deen is a Design[er] Researcher, he explores game design in new and weird contexts. Amongst others, he created games in swimming pools, therapeutic sessions and forests. By creating games with professionals, students and non-game developers, Menno builds bridges between industries, disciplines and people. As a result, he fosters the inclusion of new perspectives and domains into the creative industry of game development.

Menno worked as incubation manager at Dutch Game Garden. He helped start-ups to enter the game industry or to search for new markets for their interactive experiences. Within a revamped incubation program, Menno brought start-ups together and had them learn from and with each other. In two years, the program has grown from zero to 40+ participants, all engaging and growing their businesses. 

Menno initiated the Games [4‚Ä¶] Jams. These game jams bring people together to develop a working game in a rather short time span. The jams produce case studies in the domains of inclusion, health, education and cultural heritage. Most of all, they inspire and connect. 

Together with Mark van Kuijk, Menno founded the game studio Lapp. Lapp develops prototypes and performs user tests for games that stimulate meaningful interactions between (grand)parents and children. Combining two playing styles and cognitive abilities in one game in order to resonate both experiences and invite players to communicate with one another.

As chairman of Games [4Diversity], Menno tries to improve the representation and inclusion of socio-cultural minorities in games. By organising gamejams, talks and informal mixers, he brings people together to inspire and connect on a rich variety of subjects. In line with this work, Menno organises the annual (Dutch) Courage showcases at GDC and Gamescom. He sets up industry meetings in Utrecht and  organised various conferences and summits. 

Currently, Menno works on games that fight cancer, artrose, loneliness and other (mental) health related subjects. All his work has one thing in common: connecting people in playful manners.

summary:
New technology creates a seemingly unstoppable stream of information that reaches us from all sides. We can try to ingnore that stream, we can try to build a dam to contain it, we can try to drink all the water coming at us. 
I believe we have to find a different approach. I believe we have to learn to swim and learn to build boats that can navigate this wild stream of information. That will help us achieve goals that we can now only dream of.

This is why I started Dutch Rose Solutions, to create the means to navigate the flood of information.

I try to live by the words of the following wise men: 
- ‚ÄòThere is beauty in simplicity‚Äô, free after Albert Einstein;
- 'Simplicity is the ultimate form of sophistication', Leonardo da Vinci
- ‚ÄòIf I have seen further it is by standing on the shoulders of Giants‚Äô, by Sir Isaac Newton;
- 'Learning does not take place if an idea remains unchallenged', by Karl Popper

Specialties: making things simple
augmented reality, business dashboards, content strategy, collaboration, user experience, social media

summary:
Benno is an experienced strategy advisor with a passion for entrepreneurship. His expertise lies in connecting public and private parties, companies and ideas with an eye towards renewal and growth, and he often plays a coaching role in his support of operational change. Benno seeks to encourage action through innovation, and is committed to entrepreneurial development

As a senior partner at Roland Berger, Benno concentrates on technology-intensive industries and the life sciences, public-private partnerships and academia. He facilitates innovation management, growth strategy and business model development. Entrepreneurship is central to his work, and he inspires it among his clients.

Benno is Member of the Board of The Netherlands Academy of Technology and Innovation, AcTI, a unique and independent platform and network of distinguished persons committed to societal and cultural issues relating to technology, innovation and economic application of science and technology.

Benno is elected Director of the Royal Holland Society of Sciences and Humanities (Koninklijke Hollandsche Maatschappij der Wetenschappen) The KHMW, established in 1752, aims at promoting science and aspires to bridge the gap between science and society.

Benno founded the Young Entrepreneurs Network in Delft in 1995, which grew into YES!Delft in 2005 ‚Äì a program which has offered education, guidance and coaching to hundreds of students in setting up their businesses. Benno holds advisory positions in several fast growing technology intensive ventures

Benno co-founded the Roland Berger office in Amsterdam in 2002. Roland Berger is the only European player among the leading international strategy and management advisory firms. Roland Berger brings a mix of consulting, technology and capital to offer its clients the maximum in added value. Whether companies, countries, institutions or entire communities, its clients are leaders in their fields. From strategic visions to restructuring, Roland Berger provides services of the highest excellence.

name: Henk van Ess
skills: ['Teaching', 'Teamwork', 'New Media', 'Blogging', 'Social Media', 'Journalism', 'SEO', 'Multimedia', 'Publishing', 'Public Relations', 'Online Research', 'Online Marketing', 'Editing', 'Internet Research', 'Digital Media', 'Social Networking', 'Newspapers', 'Magazines', 'Research', 'Copywriting']
summary:
Henk van Ess is a distinguished Dutch investigator, researcher, and open source intelligence (OSINT) expert with a focus on social media investigations. Collaborating with global media organizations and law enforcement agencies, he has honed his skills to advance research and investigative methodologies using open-source data. 

A sought-after speaker and educator, Henk has shared his knowledge at conferences and workshops across the globe. As the author of numerous books and articles, he covers subjects such as internet research, social media, search with artificial intelligence and clever use of Google. He also contributes to the creation of innovative tools and techniques for online search and investigation.

He is an assessor for the International Fact Checking Network, and visiting lecturer of Free Tech Academy in Berlin and Arizona State University in Phoenix.  Pulitzer-prize winners from The Wallstreet Journal and Washington Post work with Henk to do web investigations and social media research and contra intuitive use of Google. He trained their editors and also did bootcamps at NBC News, IRE, Global Witness, Buzzfeed, Google, Axel Springer and ITV. So now and then Henk assists in complicated International law cases, by finding new and surprising facts online.

 Van Ess is a regular guest of conferences for reporters ( IRE, GIJC, SKUP, and CIJ. ) recruiters, librarians, banks, educational organizations, or other groups that share his passion to find online information via lateral and literal thinking.

 Some call Henk "one of the most creative" in his field but when you say that to him, he will immediately ask you for your source. (Mr. Lehren, NBC News, LinkedIn recommendations). 

His workshops are in English, German or Dutch.  Henk is a one-stop shop for setting up a team for professional open-source investigation / competitive intelligence inside your firm, by training trainers. 

He writes books in D, F, NL, and ENG about Google, data journalism, web research, Fantastic Facebook formulae, and privacy. He is co-author of the Verification Handbook  and Richtig Recherchieren, (2017). In 2023 he wrote Google Code Editie Politie. His former website was quoted by Google under  ªWhat We ºre Reading º.  Henk was a member and trainer of the Emmy-awarded open-source movement Bellingcat.

His personality type is Assertive Logician INTP-A but he thinks that the psychology behind that system is flawed. If you wonder why this text is in the third person: it must be an INTP-A thing.

summary:
After clinical work experience as Radiotherapy technician (Oslo) as well as Physical therapist (Drachten), I graduated my master Clinical health science at the Utrecht university in 2007.
In 2013 I started a PhD trajectory besides my clinical work as a physical therapist. This was a cooperation between Nij Smellinghe Hospital and the University of Maastricht. This gave me the opportunity to combine my scientific research with all the dynamics in daily practice. Main focus of my scientific work and PhD thesis was a transition of perioperative care on the orthopaedic ward of Nij Smellinghe Hospital. After finishing my PhD in 2018 I worked 1,5 year in OLVG hospital in Amsterdam as project leader value based health care. Nowadays I'm program leader in perioperative health care innovations in Nij Smellinghe hospital and I started a professoriate on the same topic at the Hanze University in Groningen on November the 1st 2021.

summary:
To transition! I am working for change in how we organise health and education in our society. I am currently leading the MSc Healthy Ageing Professional at the Hanze university in Groningen. This master is a fine example of a broad interprofessional community developing and researching innovative learning strategies in the field of sustainability transitions and social innovations. In our master the aim is to reposition and reorganise health in society. 

I believe professionals have a key role in this change to better governance and better education. For this education needs to re-invent itself. I especially see a major role for more contextualised and more collaborative learning. Universities of applied science and especially the Hanze University is a frontrunner in facilitating learning by both embedding and integrating education and research in real practice.

summary:
‚ÄúWhere your talents and the world's needs cross, there lies your vocation.‚Äù [Aristotles] 

Innovatie wordt niet gedreven door het feit of het technisch mogelijk is, maar of het waarde toevoegt voor de eindgebruikers. Kunnen en willen zij het gebruiken?

Innovatie in de zorg wordt nog te vaak ontwikkeld vanuit een ander perspectief. Kan de zorg effici√´nter en goedkoper?

Mijn vrouw Hester, kreeg de diagnose Alzheimer toen ze 50 was en ruim 5 jaar later stierf ze aan de gevolgen ervan. Elke dag was ik getuige van haar oneerlijke strijd voor waardigheid en zelfredzaamheid. Als mantelzorger werd ik overbelast met het organiseren en regelen van de zorg. 

De zorg in Nederland is vastgeroest in hokjes en silo‚Äôs. Het systeem is kapot. Verandering is noodzakelijk en dan mogen we niet alleen naar anderen kijken. Wat is onze eigen rol hierin? Wat is de rol van de informele zorg in de wijk?

#focusopwatwelkan

Vanuit de praktijk zie ik kansen en mogelijkheden voor innovatie in de zorg die de positieve focus leggen op wat dus w√©l kan en daarin verbindend zijn. Ontwikkeld met en voor de mensen in de zorg.

Wereldwijd zijn er m√©√©r dan 60 miljoen mensen met dementie. Met mijn kennis en ervaring wijd ik mij volledig aan het welzijn voor mensen met dementie en de familie (mantelzorgers).


Inspire(d) to change !

Floor Vermeulen (Boskoop, 31 juli 1984) is vanaf juni 2021 burgemeester van Wageningen. Daarvoor was hij zes jaar gedeputeerde en loco-commissaris van de Koning in de provincie Zuid-Holland.

Naast zijn functie als burgemeester is hij actief als voorzitter van het landelijke platform Ruimte voor Lopen, lid van de raad van toezicht van MARIN in Wageningen en lid van de Strategische Adviesraad Mobility en Built Enviroment van TNO in Delft. 

Voor de VVD is hij van jongs af aan actief geweest als lid van het lokale en regiobestuur, lid van de landelijke partijraad en lid en voorzitter van diverse commissies en als statenlid en gedeputeerde voor de VVD Bestuurdersvereniging. 

Floor studeerde politieke wetenschappen aan de Universiteit Leiden (BA, 2007) en volgde tijdens zijn studie het Honours Programme Europees Recht.

skills: ['Public Speaking', 'Inspiration', 'Writing', 'Corporate Communications', 'Social Networking', 'Business Networking', 'Organizational Leadership', 'Marketing Communications', 'Team Motivator', 'Change Management', 'Crisis Management', 'Management', 'Personal Development', 'Dutch', 'Entrepreneurship', 'Operations Management', 'Social Media']
summary:
Iedereen heeft een verhaal. Mijn verhaal gaat over omgaan met tegenslag en verandering. Over keuzevrijheid en doorzettingsvermogen. Over samenwerken en verbinden. Hoe bepaal je jouw houding.
Op 24-jarige leeftijd word ik onterecht veroordeeld voor drugssmokkel. Ik krijg 10 jaar celstraf en beland onschuldig in een gevangenis in Marokko.

Onafhankelijk onderzoek van het ministerie van Buitenlandse Zaken wijst uit dat er geen enkel bewijs is. Ondanks de onterechte opsluiting en het harde gevangenisleven besluit ik er het beste van te maken. Ik relativeer, waardeer het kleine, koester wat ik heb en zet mijn verdriet, woede en frustratie om in positieve energie. Na 1637 dagen kom ik vrij: sterker, positiever en veerkrachtiger dan ooit.

Men zegt dat mijn verhaal even bizar als inspirerend is. Met mijn levensveranderende ervaring heb ik inmiddels tienduizenden mensen geraakt, ontroerd, gemotiveerd en verder geholpen in het leven. Mijn boeken zijn gelezen door een paar honderdduizend mensen en dit aantal blijft groeien! Hier blijf ik zo dankbaar voor!
Een lezing bijwonen of mijn boek(en) lezen zet je aan het denken, maakt je bewuster en geeft een enorme energieboost!

My passion lies in assisting pension plan boards in meeting their fiduciary responsibilities towards their beneficiaries and other stakeholders. As an advisor on investment related topics I intend to translate relevant academic insights into practical solutions for institutional investors and act as their trusted advisor across a broad range of investment related matters. In the past I have taken up this role at both for-profit (fiduciary advisor) as in non-profit organisations (pension plans), for instance at Philips Pension Fund and at AZL Fiducional (NN investment partners) as a client advisor.

In my current role as Senior Policy Advisor Investments I advise the Board of Trustees of ABP Pension Fund (with 550 bn euros in assets) in the Netherlands on Investment Strategy, ESG and oversight over the Investments that are outsourced to the Asset Manager (APG Investments).

Next to that I am a Assistant Professor of Finance at Maastricht University in the Netherlands. I teach the MSc course Institutional Investors, supervise MSc and PhD students and conduct research on a wide range of investment related topics. For instance, the impact of ESG on risk and return, mutual funds, active/passive investing, manager selection and style analysis. I am a fellow of the European Centre for Corporate Engagement (ECCE) at Maastricht University. The centre combines all research into ESG investing at Maastricht University. name: J√∂rgen Raymann
skills: ['Coaching', 'Social Media', 'Dutch', 'Event Management', 'Holidays', 'Public Relations', 'Advertising', 'Parties', 'Change Management', 'Entrepreneurship', 'Interim Management', 'Marketing Communications', 'Peace', 'New Media', 'Social Networking', 'Marketing Strategy', 'Management', 'Management Consulting', 'Operations Management', 'Motivation']
summary:
Inspiratie is de bron van succes. De juiste mindset, jezelf en je medewerkers continue ontwikkelen, veerkrachtig zijn. Zodat wanneer een crisis je raakt, je terug kunt veren, het roer om kunt gooien, jezelf kunt herpakken. Ik hou ervan om mensen in organisaties rondom deze onderwerpen te inspireren en adviseren. En met inbreng van mijn eigen ervaring maak ik het persoonlijk en toegankelijk.   

2020 zou voor mij het jaar zijn geweest dat alles goed zou komen. Na een dip in 2016 waarbij ik alles bijna kwijtraakte, was ik langzaam maar zeker aan het terugkrabbelen. Ik had begin 2020 alles eindelijk weer redelijk op een rijtje, er was weer een lichtpuntje aan de horizon. Ik had een goed lopend programma bij BNR en ik kreeg zowaar een hoofdrol in ‚ÄúHello Dolly‚Äù de musical naast o.a. Simone Kleinsma, iets waar wel van heb durven dromen maar nu was het werkelijkheid.
En toen kwam waar daar opeens Covid-19 dat virus wat ver weg leek maar opeens aan een ieder zijn voordeur stond te bonken.
Binnen een tijdsbestek van een paar maanden verdwenen gegarandeerde opdrachten als sneeuw voor de lentezon. Waaronder ook het schitteren in een musical met Simone Kleinsma en Paul de Leeuw en nog vele andere theatercollega‚Äôs.
Gelukkig had ik 2 jaar daarvoor besloten dat het roer om moest. Ik wilde meer doen om bedrijven te helpen met de zelfontwikkeling van hun werknemers en ondernemers helpen met mindset sessies om veerkracht te ontwikkelen. Twee onderwerpen, waarin ik mezelf ervaringsdeskundige mag noemen.
 
Ik begon met het bijspijkeren van mijn kennis op het gebied van performance management en complexe ondernemings vraagstukken tijdens de crisis. Sinds 2019 ben ik Chief Inspirational Officer binnen Lenard and Lenard. Dit nadat ik eerst zelf een periode ben bijgestaan door hen om door mijn eigen storm te varen. 
Ik ben nu inzetbaar bij bedrijven om ze positief in beweging te krijgen en ze anders naar zichzelf maar ook naar de markt te kijken. Want een ding is zeker, Covid-19 is voor ons allemaal in welke vorm dan ook een  game changer. In mijn huidige rol probeer ik ondernemers en organisaties zoveel mogelijk te laten praten over hun uitdagingen maar ook over hun kansen die deze rare periode ook met zich meebrengt. 

Kortom, met de juiste mindset geloof ik niet alleen, maar weet ik zeker dat er heel veel mogelijk is. De kunst voor organisaties is een gezonde cultuur te cre√´ren waarin mensen makkelijk tot een positieve mindset komen. Om te inspireren en ge√Ønspireerd te worden nog betere resultaten te behalen.

On the way to DALL‚Ä¢E 2's beta launch, I -as part of a small group of people- tested that AI for unwanted biases through creative experimentation, conceived new relevant product concepts inspired by the AI‚Äôs capabilities and helped OpenAI find high profile Dutch creative professionals as well as renowned Dutch artists to be DALL‚Ä¢E 2‚Äôs first artistic ambassadors.

After DALL‚Ä¢E 2 was made accessible to the public, also our research phase crew of creatives were allowed monetising our historically significant creative explorations. DALL‚Ä¢E's launch served as blueprint launching ChatGPT, sept. '22.

summary:
After completing my military service, I worked some years as an assistent auditor and as an accountant in the commercial sector. During these years I completed a BA in economics in education. 
Subsequently, I  obtained a position as a teacher in economics and statistics at a secondary school for evening courses. 
At the same time I started my career as a civil servant at the Dutch Ministry of Economic Affairs, and combining this position with a Masters study at the Erasmus University of Rotterdam (in the evening hours).
In 1980 I started my career as a statistical researcher in the Department of Manufacturing Statistics, firstly as an assistant project leader in ICT projects and later on as a statistical researcher. 
In August 1994 I joined the Statistical Methods Department of Statistics Netherlands and worked as a researcher in different microdata projects. From March 2002 to September 2003 I joined the Netherlands Bureau for Economic Policy Analysis to work for the ICT and Productivity (ICA) Project. 
In September 2003 I returned to the Statistical Methods Department of Statistics Netherlands. Since 1 February 2006 I  am working as a senior researcher at the Science and Technology Section (belonging to the Division of Business Statistics) of Statistics Netherlands.  
In January 2009 I obtained my Phd. at Delft University of Technology on the bases of research published during the last ten years.  My promoters were Prof. Dr. Alfred Kleinknecht of Delft University of Technology and Prof. Dr. Bert Balk (ERIM, Erasmus University Rotterdam).

Specialties: International expert on the econometric analysis of firm level data in the field of ICT and innovation and the link between innovation and firm performance. Expert on statistical methods for the analysis of time series. 

Since my reteriment I am working as a Tutor in Math, Statistics and Economics for High-School, Bachelor and (pre)Master students.

I am a mathematician with generalist software engineering expertise.

On the software side, I am especially interested in scientific computing (machine learning/data science) and type theory (proofs of correctness). However, I have been running linux and fooling around with code for 10 years, so I have picked up a lot of miscellaneous knowledge, and would be capable of writing most languages in most positions. My favorite languages are Julia, Haskell, and Rust, and I run emacs with vim keybindings; I think that should tell you a good amount about me.

On the math side, I mainly studied category-theory adjacent fields in my bachelors (graduate classes in Algebra, Algebraic Topology, and Algebraic Geometry), and I did my bachelor's thesis on Applied Category Theory. In my master's I'm working on the applied side, so I'm studying probability and statistics. I hope to bring these two fields together in future research.

summary:
I am a Singaporean who received my Ph.D. in mathematics from Texas A&M University in 2017, after which I spent 2 years as a postdoc at IMPAN in Warsaw, Poland. Following that, I was at Leiden University's Mathematical Institute as a postdoc for 3 years. In May 2023 I will be taking up a professorship at Jilin University's School of Mathematics.

My research lies on the interface between Banach algebras and large scale geometry of metric spaces, with connections to group theory, dynamics, inverse semigroups, and K-theory.

Besides mathematics research, I am also interested in mathematics education. Before I went to the United States for my Ph.D., I taught in a high school in Singapore for 3 years. I have also taught at college level in the United States and the Netherlands. 

Through my work, I have had opportunities to learn new concepts, analyze them, use them in new situations, collaborate with others, and communicate my results in writing and in oral presentations.

summary:
Victor joined the University of Cape Town‚Äôin 2007. He then worked for Shell international in the Netherlands as Research Statistical analyst responsible for business mathematical modeling in the Knowledge Management Department. His research involves dynamic business modeling, including multilevel structural equation modeling, linear and non-linear interactive class modeling and latent growth curves. Past research endeavors included publications to repuatble journals (SACLA, IEEE and ICEL) on knowledge management systems models and inference. 

Currently, apart from providing lectures in Functional Analysis and Mathematical Methods much of the work is focused on measure theories, in sigma algebras. It is anticipated that special fields and operational theories could be an effective way to induce synergy between far spaced domains, henceforth speeding up conversion of theory into practice.       

Other research interests include, statistical inference in business processes, probability theories as applied to business modeling, knowledge management systems models, and e-Business Strategy. 


Other vested interests include applications of Mathematical modeling in business and inference; using Atlas ti in qualitative consultancy and research. 

From  mathematics to computing and modeling "business", it has all been trying to see what is transitory in what is permanent and what is permanent in what is transitory. Once some levels of mastery is obtained, we can then be more certain in isolating and applying our specific reasons to specific areas of need!

summary:
I have over 25 years of experience in international education. Since August 2019 I am working as a math teacher at an international school in Amsterdam. Before that I was International Deputy Principal for Academic Affairs at the Nazarbayev Intellectual School of Astana in Kazakhstan from 2014-2019. The school is part of a large scale educational reform project in the country, bringing international best practices to schools while maintaining and building on strengths already present in the country's educational system. In my role I guided the development of the IB Diploma and Middle Years Programme at the school as well as contributing to the improvement of school management and leadership. 

From 2005-2014 I worked for the IB, first in Geneva, supporting schools in the Africa, Europe and Middle East region in their implementation of the MYP and guiding them through authorization and evaluation. In this role I also trained and managed workshop leaders, consultants and site visitors. Later I worked in Washington DC for the IB in the design and monitoring of the global authorization and evaluation processes as well as in designing services for schools to support them during the authorization process. 

I started my career at a school in the Netherlands, where I worked for 7 years teaching mathematics at secondary level and leading the international section and Dutch bi-lingual section of the school through authorization and successful implementation of the IB Middle Years Programme.



My areas of expertise are curriculum design and development (with a particular emphasis on mathematics), international education, design of accreditation processes and design and provision of teacher training. I also very much enjoy teaching mathematics. I work well independently while also thriving in teams. I am an excellent communicator and strategic thinker as well as being results oriented and an effective planner and organizer. I have a good eye for detail and interdependencies while maintaining the big picture and moving new ideas forward.

in July 2021 I ended my High School Teacher Physics (eerste graads) position at the Maurick College in Vught, The Netherlands. Before that, for at least 10 years, I worked for Philips Healthcare in The Netherlands where I have been leading research teams which focussed on building and validating prototypes for new diagnostic and therapeutic methods, mainly in the fields of Image Guided Interventions (IGI) and Minimal Invasive Surgery. Clinical application areas include Cardio/Vascular (C/V), Oncology and Neurology. name: Jasper Croll
skills: ['Matrix models', 'Adaptive Dynamics', 'physiologically structured population models ', 'C (Programming Language)', 'MATLAB', 'R (Programming Language)']
summary:
I am a theoretical biologist with a wide interest in ecology and evolution. In my work I aim to understand how population structure changes due to environmental influences and how population structure drives the ecological and evolutionary dynamics of populations and communities. Herein I am especially interested in the feedback mechanisms that link individual energetics, life history characteristics and population dynamics. Although my scientific work is aimed to broaden the theoretical understanding of ecological systems, I am also interested in applying these theoretical insights to specific systems in the context of management questions. 

I currently use matrix models to explore how interactions within a family network affect the dynamics of a family of social individuals and how this affects the dynamics of populations of endangered animal species. 

During my PhD I explored how plasticity in individual growth curves affect the dynamics of structured populations. To do so, I connected dynamic energy budget models to size structured population models. I used this framework to study the effect density dependent growth in harvested North Sea fish stocks. 

In addition, I have a broad background in teaching biology, ecology and evolution at various levels, which I consider an important aspect of a scientific career.

name: Lowlands Institute for BioElectric Medicine (Wired)
summary:
The Lowlands Institute for Bioelectric Medicine was founded by cardiologist-electrophysiologist prof. Dr. Natasja MS de Groot and Cardiothoracic surgeon Dr. Yannick J.H.J Taverne. The institute is a fusion of their research groups, which are respectively translational electrophysiology (department of Cardiology) and translational Cardiothoracic Surgery (department of Cardiothoracic Surgery). Within this institute  an network of medical doctors, engineers, biologist, patients and companies collaborate to implement innovation in biology, technology in daily clinical practice to diagnose and treat diseases caused by bio-electrical dysfunction with emphasis on the heart.
Bioelectronic medicine encompasses innovative approaches to detect and treat diseases by utilizing bioelectricity. Bioelectricity refers to generation of electrical currents by conversion of chemical energy produced by living organisms. Bioelectrical signals are at the heart of cell-cell communication and therefore essential for organization, morphogenesis, and regeneration of cells. Bioelectrical dysfunction causes dysfunctional organs and hence a variety of challenging diseases e.g. cardiovascular, neuromuscular-, skin- neurological-, auto-immune-, psychiatric-, metabolic- diseases and cancer. Deciphering bioelectricity and subsequently modulating it, revolutionizes prevention, screening, diagnosis and treatment of these diseases. Recent molecular studies have highlighted the importance of bioelectrical signaling; the electrochemical nature of cells and their micro-environments encompasses a tight coupling between cellular physiology and bioelectricity. Combined with the realization that externally applied electrical fields can modulate multicellular processes, interest in bio-electricity of biological systems has been revived. The bioelectrical system is the quintessential link between form (morphology) and function (physiology) and is the gamechanger in translational research.

summary:
My research transcends the classic boundaries between biology and engineering to visualize single molecules in living cells. For this purpose, I combine advanced control strategies, algorithm development, and computational microscopy technology. 

The single molecules that I focus on are messenger ribonucleic acids (mRNAs). All cells use a large set of mRNAs that provide the essential link between genomic information in the DNA and proteins that comprise the molecular machines that are the basis of every living organism. At the University of Massachusetts I have developed a framework for optimal image analysis to detect and localise single molecules, and have performed single molecule experiments in three dimensions. Currently, I am imaging single molecules at the University of Oxford in the living brain using newly designed adaptive microscopes that I have built especially for this purpose. 

Professional & Technical Skills: Quantitative Analysis ‚Ä¢ Image Processing ‚Ä¢ Single-Molecule Microscopy ‚Ä¢ Adaptive Optics ‚Ä¢ Pattern Recognition ‚Ä¢ Machine Learning ‚Ä¢ Smart Sensing ‚Ä¢ Big Data Analytics ‚Ä¢ Leadership ‚Ä¢ Critical Thinking ‚Ä¢ Problem Solving ‚Ä¢ Microsoft Office ‚Ä¢ Zemax ‚Ä¢ Matlab ‚Ä¢ Cuda ‚Ä¢ Java ‚Ä¢ C++ ‚Ä¢ SAP

summary:
I am a skilled researcher (PhD in Biophysics) who is driven by interpreting complex (noisy) datasets to uncover the hidden patterns that lie within. I enjoy working in (multidisciplinary) teams and making a positive impact on society. 

I've worked with data of many different varieties: both qualitative and quantitative Biological data, biochemical measurements, microscopy data, force spectroscopy data, single-molecule FRET, biochemical data, Geographical data, Satellite data, and more. 

In general, my expertise lies in predictive (i.e. statistical) modeling, with an emphasize on stochastic (i.e. random) processes. 
During my PhD I have focussed interpreting noisy biological data, using a combination of statistical physics, techniques such as Bayesian inference and Maximum Likelihood estimation, Monte Carlo simulations, simulated annealing and machine learning.  In particular, I have a initiated a project to model the specificity of a genome editing enzyme: CRISPR-Cas9. 

My skills/expertise:
* PhD in biological physics. Solid knowledge of mathematics, statistics, physics and biology. 
* computer programming: Python (incl. Pandas, Numpy & Matplotlib) , R (incl. tidyverse), C++ , MATLAB 
* Experience with working in multidisciplinary research teams. 
* Experience in supervising student projects. 
* predictive/statistical modeling, Monte Carlo simulations, parameter estimation
* Working with (large) datasets: Interpretation, analyzing and visualisation. 
* Physical modeling/Mathematics, multidimensional optimization, Monte Carlo simulations. 

I am eager to work in new fields, collaborate with those coming from different expertise, and hopefully help them by using my own expertise in analyzing their data. 

Feel free to contact me via LinkedIn or at: klein.misha@gmail.com

summary: My research centers around the manipulated behavior exhibited by ants that are infected with fungal species of the genus Ophiocordyceps; the so-called "zombie ants". I use this fungus-insect interaction as a model system to study the fungal natural products involved in host manipulation and their effects on insect behavioral pathways. The overarching aim of this work is to elucidate how parasites can affect the behavior of their hosts, how behavior is regulated and dysregulated at the molecular level, and what neuroactive compounds are involved. In this endeavor, I am using an integrative approach that combines multi-omics techniques, molecular microbiology techniques, infection biology, chronobiology, and animal behavior.

I would describe myself as an ambitious student who constantly tries to gain as many experiences as possible and chases life-changing opportunities. That is why after completing my bachelor's studies in Molecular Biology and Genetics, I decided to step out of my comfort zone and leave my family (my husband and my wonderful pet) in Greece and start my master's in Biomedical Sciences at Maastricht University. 

During my academic years, I gained a deep insight into a biomedical field that I truly love and I focused on researching cancer's pathogenicity and molecular pathways. My passion for research and creativity led me to participate in SRBW, a student-run biology workshop, as a conference speaker the first year and an organizer the second year. The challenges I faced concerning time and sources management not only taught me how to effectively handle stressful situations and be creative in coming up with solutions but also motivated me to express and stand for my ideas.       

Besides gaining a lot of practical experience, I was given the opportunity to conduct two main internships at BRFAA, a biomedical research institute in Athens, and at Kofinas Fertility Group in Manhattan. These experiences were a milestone in my scientific and personal development as they broadened my horizons and motivated me to collaborate with international people and embrace different cultures.      

Next to my bachelor studies, I worked at a cafe. Having a side job as a waitress did not only help me stand on my own feet from a young age but also allowed me to join the labor market early and learn how to effectively collaborate with colleagues and employers.     

In my spare time, I enjoy having long conversations with friends along with a cup of coffee, reading books, and also writing literary texts and poems. I value a lot devoting quality time to my family and making memories with them.

summary:
When I was a child, I first came into contact with science through patient conferences, where I was inspired by the passionate researchers spending their time trying to understand a rare disease. I admired their dedication to improving the lives of even just a few people. Knowing how advancements in science had given me a chance to live a normal life, I decided that my goal is to do the same for other people.

Today, I am training for a career in science and in my spare time I am a passionate advocate and volunteer for the cause of making medicines accessible and affordable for everyone around the world.

In 2021, I graduated cum laude and with Honours from an interdisciplinary Bachelor's programme combining biomedicine with public health and information.

Currently, I am in the second year of a Master's in "Cancer, Stem Cells and Developmental Biology". I have recently completed an internship at the Hubrecht Institute in the group of Wouter de Laat. Through this internship, I explored my interest in epigenetics, and in particular the effects of alterations in the 3D genome structure in cancer. Currently, I am looking for a final six month internship. After I graduate, I hope to continue a career in cancer research, contributing towards a better understanding of the molecular and (epi)genetic underpinnings of cancer, and by extension targets for improved treatments.

When I am not working or volunteering, I enjoy reading books, letting my creativity run free through writing short stories, as well as traveling and capturing memorable moments in photographs.

name: Danny Incarnato
skills: ['RNA Biology', 'Object Oriented Perl', 'Epigenetics', 'Group Leadership', 'University Teaching', 'Bioinformatics', 'RNA Structure', 'Next Generation Sequencing', 'Higher Education']
summary: Dr. Incarnato is a molecular biologist with extensive training and experience in epigenetics, genomics and RNA biology. During his graduate training in the lab of Prof. Oliviero, he begun developing his research line mainly focused on understanding how RNA folds into intricate structures to exert its functions. He developed several cutting-edge next-generation sequencing (NGS)-based methods for the study of nucleic acid modifications (MAB-seq [5-formylcytosine/5-carboxylcytosine] and 2Ome-seq [2'-O-methylation]), and structure (CIRS-seq, SPET-seq, RAPiD-MaPseq, and multiplexed SHAPE-MaP). In 2019, he joined the University of Groningen (the Netherlands) as assistant professor of molecular genetics, where he established his laboratory. The lab was the first at the beginning of the COVID-19 pandemics to determine the structure of the SARS-CoV-2 RNA genome in living infected host cells, identifying several highly conserved RNA structural elements harboring druggable pockets. Dr. Incarnato's research keeps pushing the development of methods for the study of RNA structure and dynamics in living cell, including the recent introduction of 2-aminopyridine-3-carboxylic acid (2A3), the to date most powerful reagent for RNA SHAPE analysis, and DRACO (Deconvolution of RNA Alternative COnformations), a computational method able to deconvolute coexisting alternative RNA structural conformations (and their relative stoichiometries) from RNA chemical probing experiments.

summary:
I consider myself as a hard working and dedicated person. For me it is important to be reliable and I will do everything to keep that reputation. I like to help others, although I am learning now not to overdo that and mark my boundaries. That matches with delivering high quality work.

In my life and work I found out that it is satifying to always have a goal and some sort of challenge. So when a job is finished I will look for another task, no matter how big or small. I see a disappointment as a chance to learm something new. It keeps me flexible, awake and optimistic.

I am happy with my part-time job as a high school teacher biology. It appears to be fitting me and I love to work with so many people. As a hobby I work with horses, and sometimes other animals. I train my own Dartmoor pony in academic dressage, driving, and allround skills. I like to train people and animals. My dream is to do this at the same time.

Besides that I feel like a real scientist. I am especially interested in animal ethology (behaviour), anatomy, physiology, and parasitology. According to me spirituality and science can exist side by side, which will bring great things in the future. 

With my own bussiness Wonderpony, where I do horse and donkey worm egg counts in dung samples, I can perform the thouroughness and science skills I like to keep up. The advising of the horse owners and the networking is one of the advantages of this part-time job.

Nature simply fascinates me. I am outside as much as I can and I like to share that with others. I use intuition a lot while working with nature or animals. It has learned me so much in the past. 

I the future I would love to stay a teacher. I would like to combine that with biology or educational research, scientific research, or other activities. Like horseback riding, animal training and care/health, working outdoors or field work, lab work or anything like this. Any job that contains the elements of my passions is interesting for me.

As a child I was intrigued by the documentaries shown on Animal Planet, with Steve Erwin as one of my childhood heroes. To the people around me it was no surprise that I decided to study biology after I finished High School. During my studies I was amazed by the complexity of biology on a cellular scale. I found a new interest in trying to understand the mechanisms behind diseases and how you can use biology to fight them. 

My dream of becoming a scientist was shattered during my first internship. During those 6 months I came to the realization that there was no match between me and a life of pipettes, microscopes and cell cultures. 

A specialization in Science Based Business prepared me for a career outside of the scientific world and I decided to apply for a Traineeship at KPN. The same people surrounding me were surprised this time. It was hard to understand how a background in biology made sense for a career in IT and Telecommunications. 

Fortunately I found KPN Security and I quickly realized how my background in biology could help me in cybersecurity. Since the day of that realization I call myself a Digital Immunologist, someone who uses knowledge of pathogens and immune systems for cyber security.

In September I will start my communication profile as final component of my Master's during which I will gain further knowledge and experience in science communication. In September I will therefore also start with my internship at NEMO Kennislink during which I will gain more experience in the field of science journalism.

I co-lead the Center for Digital Innovation together with Daniel Grenfell-Lee. We are part of DSM‚Äôs Science & Innovation unit Biodata & Translation established In 2022. The global Center has five global Teams: Translational Data Science & Insights, Data Analytics, Bioinformatics and Modeling, Lab4.0 & Automation, Data Automation & Analytics.

Our global Teams work from the offices and labs in Delft, the Netherlands; Heerlen, the Netherlands; Kaiseraugst, Switzerland; Lexington, US; Columbia; US. We team-up in Science & Innovation projects with our colleagues in Animal Nutrition & Health, Human Nutrition & Care, Taste, Texture & Health, and Biosciences & Process Innovation.

Besides, I am currently assigned as Senior Science Fellow Bioinformatics, Modeling & Data Science. My previous functions at DSM involved R&D management and strategy for the (i) Bio-design & Modeling, and (ii) the Biofab lab automation groups. 

Over the years, I have managed multidisciplinary project teams for Industrial Biotech projects and support, involving: high-throughput screening, automated strain engineering, protein engineering, metabolic pathway engineering, omics data mining, sequencing, biostatistics and big data. 

I am experienced, working in innovation projects with filamentous fungi, yeast and bacteria: Saccharomyces cerevisiae, Kluyveromyces lactis, Aspergillus niger, Penicilium chrysogenum, Mortierella alpina, Bacillus subtilis, Escherichia coli and more.

summary:
I am a Group Leader and Principal Investigator at the Computational Omics Discovery Lab, where I lead a team of multidisciplinary researchers focused on developing novel therapeutic strategies for cancer.

I earned my BSc/MSc degrees in Molecular Genetics from the University of Belgrade, where I gained a strong foundation in molecular biology and genetics.

After completing my undergraduate and graduate studies, I pursued a PhD in Biochemistry/Bioinformatics at KU Leuven, where I worked with Frank Claessens' lab to study the androgen receptor's role in diverse diseases. This research has led to several publications in high-impact journals and has laid the foundation for my current work on transcription factor targeting in cancer.

Following my PhD, I conducted postdoctoral research at the Netherlands Cancer Institute, where I worked with Wilbert Zwart to investigate transcription factor action in various cancer types using omics, screening, and computational methodologies.

Throughout my career, I have been dedicated to translating scientific discoveries into clinical practice and have a passion for contributing to cutting-edge research in the field of cancer biology and therapeutics.

summary: Science and society affect each other continuously. Unfortunately, conflicts often arise due to lack of communication and/or (mutual) understanding. An excellent example is the current pandemic about which countless conspiracy theories have arisen. The giant gap between science and society renders it hardly possible for consultants and scientists to inform the public and come up with solutions that are well supported by society. Harmonising science and society ideally yields more valuable scientific research as well as a faithful and supportive society. I am currently studying the social aspect of science, its interaction with society and how miscommunication and misconceptions could be eliminated. With a special interest and a background in molecular (neuro-)biology, and future knowledge of social phenomena, I will be able to help science and society overcome conflict(s) due to misconceptions.

skills: ['Research', 'Risk Assessment', 'Ecology', 'Biodiversity', 'Conservation Biology', 'Aquatic Ecology', 'Water Management', 'Environmental Science', 'Environmental Impact Assessment', 'Sustainable Development', 'Water', 'Water Quality', 'Climate Change', 'Lecturing', 'Teaching', 'Fish', 'Conservation Issues', 'Landscape Ecology', 'Fisheries', 'Environmental Issues']
summary:
Rob S.E.W. Leuven (1957) studied biology (aquatic ecology, animal physiology, fisheries & aquaculture). His PhD-thesis concerned the impacts of acidification on the biodiversity and functioning of aquatic ecosystems. His main research interest is understanding the impact of invasive alien species and physicochemical stressors on biodiversity and functioning of aquatic ecosystems (rivers, floodplains, moorland pools, peat bogs and urban waters). 

Current research focuses on biological invasion processes, including dispersal patterns, population establishment success, physiological tolerances and biological traits of aquatic invaders, risk assessment of exotic species, effects of climate change on global redistribution of species, ecological effects and socio-economic impacts of aquatic invaders, and management of invasive species.

He was project leader of several large research projects commissioned by the World Bank, European Commission, the Netherlands Organization for Scientific Research, Netherlands Food and Consumer Safety Authority, several Dutch ministries, waterboards and non-governmental organizations. He successfully supervised 16 PhD-projects and (co)authored more than 230 papers (among which >120 ISI-WOS articles), 18 scientific books and 80 professional reports.

Research topics: Biological Invasions, Biodiversity assessment, Conservation biology, Functioning of ecosystemens, Invasive species, Ecological risk analysis, Risk assessment of alien species, River ecology. 

Teaching activities: Courses on Biodiversity and Ecological Assessment, Human and Environment, Research Skills, Ecology and Management Invasive Alien Species.

name: Esther Nolte-'t Hoen
skills: ['Cell', 'Cell Biology', 'Immunology', 'Flow Cytometry', 'Animal Models', 'Molecular Biology', 'Cell Culture', 'FACS', 'Scientific Writing', 'Immunohistochemistry', 'qPCR', 'In Vivo', 'Western Blotting', 'Life Sciences', 'Biochemistry', 'Science', 'Polymerase Chain Reaction (PCR)', 'Real-Time Polymerase Chain Reaction (qPCR)']
summary:
I have been active in research on extracellular vesicles (EVs) for more than 15 year, driven by my fascination for how cells use this advanced means of communication to exchange packages of information encoded in proteins and genetic material. Besides my focus on unraveling EV-biology, I‚Äôm also committed to EV-technology development.

Knowledge sharing and training of newcomers to the field are key to advancing the EV-field. In support of this, I (co-)organize conferences dedicated to EV research (ISEV, NLSEV, GRC) and the annual hands-on training course on EV-research at EMBL Heidelberg. I am associate editor of the main and influential journal in the field (Journal of Extracellular Vesicles, open-access). As president of the Netherlands Society for Extracellular Vesicles (NLSEV, since 2022) I support the connection of Dutch EV researchers to facilitate collaborations, share equipment, and apply for collaborative grants.

In coaching and supervision of students and young researchers, I strive to help them develop into open-minded, collaborative, and reliable scientists who can reflect on their own work and work of others with constructive criticism. I have initiated ‚ÄòVet-peersupport‚Äô, a mentoring panel within our faculty for career support of young researchers to obtain competitive funding.

My current research focuses on resolving the role of EVs in infection and inflammation, in particular on how EVs affect picornavirus-spreading and antiviral immune responses. I advocate for the importance of fundamental research in the EV field. Only through profound understanding of the pathways via which EVs are formed, collect their cargo, and transfer information, we can reveal their functional potential and optimize their use in diagnostic and therapeutic applications.

name: Rachael Cargill
summary:
I am a PhD candidate in the Kokkoris group at the Vrije Universiteit (VU), Amsterdam. My work involves the use of advanced fluorescent microscopy techniques to study the intracellular dynamics of arbuscular mycorrhizal fungal (AM fungi) networks. In addition, I am using similar techniques to understand the arrangement and structure of the AM fungal cell and cellular components. In the future, I shall be investigating nuclear dynamics.

Before my PhD position, I completed an MSc in Ecology & Evolution also at the VU. During this time, I developed a strong interest in studying AM fungi through two internship projects completed at the VU and AMOLF. I utilised various techniques to research AM fungi at different organisational scales. This work enabled me to spend nearly two years studying the same organism, using diverse approaches and adopting varied perspectives. 

Through my PhD, I aim to advance my research skills and contribute to understanding the network and cellular dynamics of an ecologically important organism. There is much to learn!

name: Alfonso Isola

summary:
Alfonso Agatino Isola was born in Catania (Italy) on February 4, 1978.

He received his M.Sc. degree in Computer Engineering from the University of Catania, in 2006, for his work on methodologies and instruments for the characterization of the Parkinson disease.  

From June 2006 till February 2007, he worked as Computer Science Researcher for the Thales Nederland B.V. in Hengelo (Netherlands).

From March 2007 till February 2010, he worked towards his Ph.D. degree at Philips Research - Hamburg and in cooperation with the Erasmus MC, University Medical Center Rotterdam. His research interests included motion-compensated iterative reconstruction algorithms, motion estimation methodologies for cardiac CT, elastic image registration, and parametric assessment of myocardial perfusion. 

He received his Ph.D. degree from the Erasmus Universiteit Rotterdam, in 2010, for his dissertation entitled  "Motion Compensated Iterative Reconstruction for Cardiac X-ray Tomography" (available at: http://hdl.handle.net/1765/19823).

From March till September 2010, he worked as Research Scientist at Philips Research - Hamburg. He studied and investigated novel image reconstruction methods for Cardiac C-arm X-ray.

From October 2010 till March 2013, he worked as Research Scientist at Philips Research - Eindhoven. He studied novel medical imaging solutions.

Since April 2013, he is working as Senior Scientist at Philips Research - Eindhoven. His research interests lie in the field of numerical optimization for radiation and thermal ablation treatment planning (e.g. Pinnacle Evolution TPS, DynaCAD Urology ablation planning, etc.), and in the field of AI and data science for cardiac diagnostic solutions (e.g. IntelliSpace Portal 12).

Reviewer for "Medical Physics", "Physics in Medicine and Biology", and "Computer Methods and Programs in Biomedicine".

Specialties: RF/MW/Cryo thermal ablation, LDR/HDR brachytherapy and EBRT planning, cardiac CT imaging, cardiac motion correction, myocardial perfusion, numerical optimization, medical physics, image processing, image reconstruction, image registration, AI, machine learning, data science, SIMD vectorized software (SSE,AVX), C, C++, C#, Python, Matlab.

Licenses & certifications: Scaled Agile SAFe¬Æ 5 Scrum Master and Product Owner/Product Manager.

summary:
My fascination with biology started at a young age and has only grown stronger over the years. During my studies, I was fortunate to work in various laboratory environments where I gained invaluable experience in the field. Through my work in the lab, I developed a deep understanding of scientific principles and research methods, which has proven to be crucial in my career as a biologist.

Over the past 3.5 years, I have had the opportunity to work in diverse laboratory settings, where I have honed my skills in molecular biology, cell culture, and microbiology. This hands-on experience has allowed me to gain insight into the complexities of biological processes and has enabled me to contribute to practical approaches to some of the challenges facing our planet.

I firmly believe that the key to a sustainable future lies in the field of biology, and I am committed to using my skills and experience to make a positive impact. Whether it is developing new technologies, conducting groundbreaking research, or working on sustainability initiatives, I am passionate about using my knowledge to contribute to a healthier and more sustainable world.

summary:
Bioinformatics and biotechnology expert specializing in unlocking the secrets of the microbiomes. 

During my Ph.D. candidacy at Technische Universiteit Delft, I focused on the transmission of antimicrobial resistance genes and engineered DNA from transgenic biosystems in nature. As a researcher in the Department of Biotechnology, I actively contributed to the TargetBio NWO funded project and the European-funded Research Platform on Antibiotic Resistance Spread through Wastewater Treatment Plants (REPARES). These projects allowed me to delve into the fascinating world of environmental biotechnology and its impact on addressing critical challenges in public health.

As a co-founder of Hologenomix Life Sciences, I am dedicated to decoding the microbial landscape within different microbiomes. Our mission is to pave the way for groundbreaking discoveries and innovative solutions in personalized medicine and environmental sustainability.

Passionate about the intersection of technology and biology, I continually seek to stay at the forefront of advancements in the field. My work is driven by a deep commitment to leveraging cutting-edge research to address global challenges, particularly in healthcare, biotechnology, and environmental sustainability.

If you're interested in exploring collaboration opportunities or discussing the exciting possibilities at the crossroads of bioinformatics, biostatistics, and environmental biotechnology, I invite you to connect with me. Together, we can make a meaningful impact and drive positive change in our world

summary:
Who am I?
# The biology teacher
My name is Jarco Smeenk and I try to spend as much time as possible with my two great passions: biology and travel. First of all, I am an experienced first-degree biology teacher with more than 17 years of experience, especially in the (pre-)exam classes of havo and vwo. I also try to reach as many students as possible via the digital way, which has resulted in the website Biologiepagina.nl. A hobby that got out of hand and has s grown into the largest free website of biology education in the Netherlands.

# The traveller
In addition to the biology website, I also made several online travel guides about my favorite destinations for a city trip. What started with a single travel blog Barcelonapagina.nl has now grown into the company Bio Web Design with a portfolio of 43 different online travel guides (full portfolio at https://rometips.nl/biowebdesign.html). The online travel guides are mainly focused on cities in Spain and Italy and active in several languages. Now, the travel portfolio has a monthly reach of 1.5 million page views, which has enabled me to make travel my work.

What am I looking for?
Sitting still is not one of my qualites, which is why you can always approach me for:
- A new (part-time) challenge in biology education focussed at exam students.
- Travel collaborations: from new content to affiliate opportunities, especially for cities in Spain and Italy

summary:
Researcher in theoretical biophysics, working closely together with experimenters. We combine analytical models with simulations to study collective dynamics in out-of-equilibrium systems, ranging from the nanoscale of proteins to the macroscale of populations. Bottom-up approach: understanding the relevant processes in living systems by starting with their basic properties and subsequently increasing complexity.

Program director of the MSc Nanobiology (joint degree program between TU Delft and Erasmus University Rotterdam) and teacher in Nanobiology, Physics and Mathematics. Courses range from introductory physics to the cutting edge of current research, including classical mechanics, special relativity, quantum mechanics, soft matter, differential geometry, and genetic engineering. Proponent of open eductation, including the writing and adaptation of open texbooks.

Specialties: analytical modeling, phenomenological descriptions, inter-disciplinary collaborations.

name: Matteo Maspero
skills: ['Medical Imaging', 'Radiation Therapy', 'Deep Learning', 'Data Analysis', 'Physics', 'Programming', 'Image Processing', 'Medical Research', 'Statistics', 'Statistical Data Analysis', 'Clinical Research', 'Artificial Intelligence (AI)', 'Research and Development (R&D)', 'Science', 'Research', 'Machine Learning', 'Healthcare', 'Medical Devices', 'Digital Imaging', 'Clinical Trials']
summary:
Matteo is an assistant professor investigating adaptive radiotherapy, image acquisition/reconstruction, segmentation, and registration with deep learning in the Computational Imaging group, Radiotherapy Department, Center of Image Sciences, Imaging and Cancer division of UMC Utrecht.

Background
Matteo was born Como (Italy) in May 1989 and studied Physics at Insubria University, graduating cum laude in March 2014. In those years, he gained interest in experimental Physics, with a predilection for particle detectors. Following this interest, he had the opportunity to perform profilometry measurements of an anti-proton beam and measure the diameter of the Sun with a pixelated silicon detector and develop a detector for spectral measurements of neutrons produced by an in-hospital linear accelerator.
After getting in touch with the hospital environment and feeling the need to broaden his horizons, he decided to step into the field of medical imaging, where, by chance, detectors are somehow involved. From May 2014 to May 2018, he was enrolled as a PhD candidate at the Radiotherapy Department of the Universitair Medisch Centrum Utrecht (The Netherlands). During his PhD project, he had the luck to discover the beauty of magnetic resonance imaging in the practical realm of radiotherapy.
Since 2018, Matteo has been a Postdoc dedicating his efforts to translate deep learning for adaptive radiotherapy clinically. Since January 2022, he has been appointed assistant professor, gaining the opportunity to facilitate clinical translation further and keeping an eye on cutting-edge software and its integration and development in the healthcare continuum.
Nowadays, medical imaging and radiotherapy are still Matteo's passions.
