summary:
Having finished a Master degree at Utrecht University in Earth Structure and Dynamics I am actively looking for job opportunities as a geologist, geophysicist or geotechnical engineer mainly in the energy sector ( ie geothermal energy, CO2 storage or oil and gas fields) or other relevant to my studies job positions.

Regarding my studies, during MSc studies, I followed a course for unconventional geo-resources which made me motivated to pursue a career in this field. For that reason, I am looking actively for full-time job opportunities in the sector of Energy as Geologist/ Geophysicist and optimally in Geothermal and Oil and Gas Exploration, or CO2 storage.

My thesis project was on researching Intra-oceanic subduction initiation with analogue modeling techniques which provided with important scientific and technical skills such as the use of laboratory equipment, process, analysis, documentation and interpretation of results with computer software. Subsequently, I started a research project on the exploration of Geothermal resource potential in mainland Greece developing a numerical model of the thermal structure of the Greek lithosphere. This was achieved by modelling the 3D geological structure of the area and use it as input for the thermal model.  During this project, I familiarized myself with the use of two different numerical modelling software. 

During my Bachelor in Geology department at the University of Athens, I did an Internship at the National Observatory of Athens having the opportunity to get an insight into how geological research in the field of Tectonics and Geodynamics works. Furthermore, I have worked along with Corinth Rift Laboratory (CRL) team for 2 years after Bachelor graduation, contributing to several field expeditions in North Peloponnese, Greece for GPS and Seismic data acquisition   

I describe myself as a committed and highly motivated scientist. Being curious, competitive, independent and seeking to expand my knowledge and skills are a few of my natural traits. I have good Fieldwork skills mainly obtained from the geological mapping of an area in Southern Greece as part of my BSc Thesis as well as spending 4 weeks in Spain collecting data for investigating the tectonic history and Inversion of Sorbas Basin in Almeria in June 2018 as part of one of my MSc courses. Throughout these projects, I learned to make meaningful interpretations of geological structures in the field and also of microstructures of rock samples to infer the deformation history of an area.

name: Nathaniel Bootes
skills: ['Data Analysis', 'SQL', 'Looker', 'Science', 'Research', 'Microsoft Office', 'Microsoft Word', 'PowerPoint', 'Microsoft Excel', 'Excel VBA', 'Tableau', 'Google BigQuery', 'Public Speaking', 'Google Sheets']
summary:
Studying rocks = Generating data-driven business insights?

I wanted to be a scientist when I was a little kid and I studied geology in university. But now I‚Äôm providing business insights and building data infrastructure. So what happened?

Well, as I finished up my studies, I did some thinking about what I wanted out of my career. I realized that despite my love for geology, I didn‚Äôt want to be a geologist forever. But I did want to do something with business (and definitely entrepreneurship at some point).

It was also at this time that I learned about data analytics as a career. I immediately saw similarities between what I love about geology research and the job of a data analyst. As I‚Äôve gained experience as an analyst, I‚Äôve only found more similarities. For both it boils down to processing a complex dataset and telling a story that is meaningful to the target audience. Simplifying complexity. 

For example, in my geologic research I collected atomic data from individual, microscopic mineral grains and published new insights on millions of years of history of an entire mountain range. In my current role, I dug into the transactions of individual customers to gain insights on churn and developed a model to identify it as soon as it‚Äôs detectable (and increased customer winbacks in the process). For both of these projects I took complex and minute details and turned them into useful knowledge. 

A related term I like is ‚Äúlumpers and splitters‚Äù, coined by Charles Darwin (himself a geologist better known for his other work). The gist of the term is that some people split every detail into its own category, whereas others lump things to focus on the broader story. Both of these are valid ways of looking at the world, but context drives whether you present the lumped or the split view to your audience.

Taking notes in the field, I may call a rock a quartzofeldspathic gneiss, but when shopping for countertops I‚Äôll ask the salesperson for the granite section. 

I see the ability to lump complex data together as a key component of being a good analyst. You need to be able to understand and work with all of the details, but aggregate and relay only the key information that can be acted upon. 

Ultimately, I see my job as taking something complex and making it understandable and actionable. Simplifying complexity. 

So whether you need to learn how a mountain formed or why success early in the sales pipeline isn‚Äôt leading to expected revenue, I‚Äôm your guy. Also, I‚Äôll be happy to tell you some interesting facts about the countertop in the cafeteria if you ask.

name: Akbar Huseynov
skills: ['40Ar/39Ar dating', 'Secondary Ion Mass Spectrometer', 'Cavity Ring-Down Spectrometer', 'Structural Analysis -  Equal Area Stereonet - Schmidt', 'Petrel, Petromod, Techlog Training with Schlumberger Montpellier', 'PaleoScan', 'Geology', 'Earth Science', 'Geological Mapping', 'LA-ICP-MS', '3D Modeling', 'Stable Isotope Analysis', 'Machine Learning', 'Microthermometry', 'Raman Spectroscopy', 'Data Analysis', 'Drone Photography', 'Drone Mapping', 'Drone Piloting', 'Qgis']
summary:
Passionate about understanding the geological complexities of the Variscan orogenic foreland basin, I specialize in both structural geology and geochemical analysis of quartz veins. 

My research delves into the origin of fluids during Variscan mountain deformation, focusing on stable isotopes (32Si, 18O, 2D) and utilizing advanced tools such as Secondary Ion Mass Spectrometry (SIMS) and Cavity Ring Down Spectroscopy (CRDS). Additionally, I employ 40Ar/39Ar dating to determine the absolute age of fluid inclusions within quartz, providing valuable insights into the kinematics and geodynamics of these veins. EPMA, Raman, and microthermometry data of fluid inclusions and samples are integral to my projects. 

Furthermore, I harness the power of Drones photogrammetry to create immersive 3D models of veins' structures in outcrops. 

Passionate about advancing our understanding of geological processes, I am eager to collaborate and make significant contributions to the field.

After completing my graduate studies at the Vrije Universiteit van Amsterdam, I did a PhD on regional geology, which focussed on fore arc tectonics in Indonesia at the Netherlands Institute for Sea Research. This was followed by a post doc at the Geological Survey of Japan, where I studied back arc evolution along the eastern Japan Sea.

 A second post doc at the University of Liverpool dealt with clastic turbidite fan systems in the Karoo (South Africa). Finally, a third post doc was conducted at the University of Brunei, where I worked with a 3D seismic volume covering the continental slope. 

I firmly entered the oil industry after landing at Shell, where I worked for 6 years. Initially, I spent three years at Rijswijk (The Netherlands) where I became involved in New Venture Projects in Africa (Mozambique, Tunisia and Nigeria). This was followed by an assignment at Shell Brunei (BSP), where I worked on deep water projects (regional framework studies, prospect mapping, volumetrics and risking and ranking of toe thrust turbidite prospects). 

I subsequently moved to Petronas Brunei, where I had the opportunity to be involved in maturing and drilling related deep water prospects in the neighbouring exploration blocks. By doing so, I completed an exploration cycle and evolved from a turbidite geologist into a deep water explorationist. 

During my final two year job assignment with Genel Energy, I was engaged in frontier hydrocarbon evaluation projects, which addressed the regional geological history of Somaliland, Ethiopia as well as western Morocco. I was also involved in the evaluation of farm-in projects in Mongolia, Kenya, Guinea, Guinea Bissau, Senegal and the Canary Islands.

My interests range from exposure and involvement with different cultures, religions, languages,  sport (hockey) and exotic asian kitchen flavours.

skills: ['Geology', 'Sedimentology', 'Deep marine geology', 'Numidian Flysch Formation', 'Western Mediterranean geology', 'Property modeling', 'Petrel', 'Euphonium / Brass Bands', 'Research', 'GIS']
summary:
I am a senior geologist working on New Ventures Exploration. I am currently the subsurface lead for a venture in West Africa. Skilled in regional to prospect scale analysis while integrating a wide range of data. I bring a specialism in stratigraphy and clastic sedimentology applied from core to outcrop and plate scales. My career at Shell has spanned the Middle East and North Africa, the Indian Ocean and Africa and the South Atlantic, from regional studies to prospect appraisal in new and held ventures. I am a regular reviewer of journal articles and have organised AAPG workshops as part of technical committees. My interests lie in academic and industrial geoscience.

Prior to joining Shell I spent 18 months at Rock Deformation Research Ltd (RDR) where I contributed to the development of content for the Studio Advisor module for Petrel which provides embedded workflows and geological guidance for the Petrel E&P platform. 

Before industry I spent 7 years within the industry funded consortium "North Africa Research Group" at the University of Manchester (UK).  The group has a specialism in fieldwork and regional geology throughout North Africa from Morocco to Egypt. During this time I was also able to continue a part time PhD with the group. I was fortunate to study the Numidian Flysch formation in Sicily and northern Tunisia with an aim to piecing together the slope depositional architectures. I also spent time trying to piece together the ambiguous basin evolution including the provenance of the deep marine sediments which remains one of the main controversies within the geology of the western Mediterranean.

summary:
Job Experience (Summary):		

Experienced production and exploration geologist / seismic interpreter with 38 years experience. 
23 years experience in seismic studies as part of field development studies, appraisal and development well proposals, reserves reporting and equity redeterminations. 
In earlier part of career had 15 years job exposure with Exploration geology and interpretation, both with prospect identification and mapping, as well as with regional seismic and geological studies. Worked in offshore delta and continental margin settings, oa the Lower Congo (Angola), Nile (Egypt), Niger (Nigeria) and Baram deltas (Borneo). Onshore studies in NE Syria (Deir ez Zor, Ash Sham), Irak (Majnoon and Kirkuk fields), Egypt (Western Desert), and Oman.  

Discipline lead for Seismic Interpretation and geo-modelling in Shell since 1999. Was regularly involved with technical peer assists and integrated milestone reviews during field development studies.  Was ‚ÄòNew Technology‚Äô focal point, as well as processing and QI focal point. Have experience with skill pool activities.

My platform of productivity is the Petrel seismic and geo-modeling toolkit, which I have used for the last 23 years. Earlier worked with Openworks / Seisworks and the Geoframe / Charisma platforms, as well as Shell‚Äôs 123Di workstations. I am experienced with 2D and 3D seismic interpretation techniques, volume interpretation, fault and structural interpretation, attribute extractions and mapping, surface gridding techniques, geo-statistics, velocity modeling and depth conversion and uncertainty analysis.
Adept at structural framework modeling, specifically of complex settings, built large and complex structural models for ao. the H-Node project, Nigeria offshore, Troll and Ormen Lange fields in Norway offshore, the  Val D'Agri field in Southern Italy and the large Lekhwair cluster in Oman.

Serge has a long-term experience as a geoscientist in both shallow and deep subsurface uses. Since 2010 he specifically focuses on subsurface energy technologies and energy transition.

Serge started his career at the former National Geological Survey of the Netherlands (RGD) in 1994 where he worked as a geologist, geophysicist and seismic interpreter on various national and international offshore studies. In 1996 he joined Panterra Geoconsultants where he worked as a geologist for the international oil and gas industry focusing on sedimentology, petrography and reservoir characterization. Serge is working for TNO since 1998. 

Serge van Gessel holds an MSc in earth sciences from the University of Utrecht where he studied Geology from 1988 until 1994. During his study he focused among others on seismic interpretation, sedimentology, structural geology, marine geology, stratigraphy and geological modeling.

summary:
After having completed a PhD in Structural Geology in 1991, I started working in the Oil &Gas industry where I have developed experience through a wide range of positions from Exploration via R&D and Business Planning to Production & Development.

I love to integrate across discipline interfaces and lead teams in a focused manner to key business decisions and improved performance/delivery.

I have implementing LEAN thinking in our organization. In the Onshore Development Team (some 100 staff) the application of LEAN methodologies has significantly accelerated business opportunity maturation and improved product quality.

As manager for new energy solutions (with a strong focus on geothermal energy) in our organization I am now fully involved with the societal and technological discussions on a sustainable energy future in the Netherlands. A successful energy transition and CO2 reduction implies that everybody will continue to have access to reliable, dependable and affordable energy. This can only be achieved through an integrated transitioning approach involving both fossil fuels and sustainable sources. In addition to the technological challenges, this debate strongly hinges on societal acceptance and the strategic decisions the players in the energy industry take.

name: Tjeerd Koopmans
skills: ['Geology', 'Project Management', 'Mining', 'Soil', 'Groundwater', 'Environmental Management Systems', 'Sustainability', 'GIS', 'ArcGIS', 'Renewable Energy', 'Modeling', 'Sustainable Development', 'Environmental Engineering', 'Civil Engineering', 'Program Management', 'Dutch', 'Aggregates', 'Hydrogeology']
summary:
Tjeerd combines general (salt) geological and (solution) mining engineering knowledge and expertise with a solid expertise in project management. His career has been on the interface of geology/mining and project management. He supports the philosophy that complex subsurface projects, with many stakeholders and risks, may only be a success when (technically) managed by a project manager with a solid knowledge of the subsurface and uncertainties, risks and controversies this brings along.

Tjeerd studied geology in Utrecht at the Faculty of Earth Sciences (MSc degree 1999) and completed two post-graduate courses in business administration (2000-2002). In mid-2001 he started his professional geological career at the Dutch Directorate-General of Public Works and Water Management (Rijkswaterstaat) in Delft as project manager raw materials supply. In 2004 he switched to the consultancy firm MWH (formerly Syncera; now part of Stantec) in Zwolle and Arnhem as project manager for sustainable use of the subsurface. In 2009 he became Technical Leader for geology and subsurface and senior project manager. In the meantime, he has obtained several project management certificates (IPMA C / D). 

In September 2012, Tjeerd joined the Mining Department of AkzoNobel Industrial Chemicals (now Nouryon) as a Geologist / Project Manager. In addition to providing internal salt geological advice, he has led complex projects in the field of storage in salt caverns (gas oil, gases and compressed air) and well integrity. In August 2017, as Manager Mining Projects, Tjeerd became responsible for all mining projects in AkzoNobel's cavern fields in Denmark and the Netherlands. After the split off of AkzoNobel's Specialty Chemicals division in October 2018 to become Nouryon, and following an internal reorganization at the end of 2018, his job changed to Lead Expert Mining Projects in November 2019, providing geological and mining technology support in several cavern storage projects.
In July 2020 Tjeerd decided to leave Nouryon to continue his career elsewhere, focusing on storage of energy (compressed air and hydrogen) in salt caverns and in October of the same year Tjheerd started his own company Mole Underground, offering geological and mining technology project management and consultancy services. In this way he wants to contribute to the energy transition.

SPECIALTIES
Salt mining technology and salt geology
Underground energy storage
Geological and mining technology project management
Dutch mining legislation
Well integrity

summary:
I wanted to become a scientist ever since my mum and dad took me to the summit of an active volcano in Tenerife. I can still vividly recall their stories about the crystallisation history of molten rocks and the lethal power behind volcanic bombs. That is why it came to no one's surprise when I started my bachelor‚Äôs in Earth Sciences at the university of Utrecht. During my bachelor, I became fascinated by the subfields of geochemistry, petrology, and volcanology, which eventually sent me off to central Mexico to monitor an active volcano. 

My research in Mexico was a wonderful experience. Not only did it teach me invaluable lessons about science, but it also allowed me to explore my own personality and grow as a person. Above all, it motivated me to enrol in the masters of Earth Structure and Dynamics at the University of Utrecht. In the next few years, I graduated top of my class (with distinction), made some amazing friends (especially during the coffee breaks), and had some unforgettable field trips (Spain). I believe that I have grown a lot since I saw that volcano in Tenerife and my drive to pursue a scientific career is stronger than ever.

My quote to live by: ''Those who dwell among the beauties and mysteries of the Earth are never alone or weary in life.'' - Rachel Carson

I am specialized in:
‚Ä¢ Stable Isotope Geochemistry
‚Ä¢ Geochronology 
‚Ä¢ Metamorphic petrology 
‚Ä¢ Petrography 


For more information you can always contact me at sander.hoogendoorn@ziggo.nl.

name: Marina  Chernyshenko
summary:
Our Earth. Amazing. Incredible. Thousands, hundreds, millions, billions of light years away, there's nothing like it, nothing that able to bear us.  We were born here. It enclosed us in itself and merged into one with its and our history for many thousands of years. It helped us invent art, ancient and modern architecture. It gave us resources. It has led our world into what we see now, cutting out layer by layer, immortalizing it with decorations in the form of sacred temples and majestic buildings.
The Earth delights and inspires.  It's so different. Cold and hard to reach at the poles. Hot and capricious in tropical zones. And so sensitive in the heart of the equator. It showed us the stars and plunged us to the bottom of the ocean. Its gave us the opportunity to learn about it and to know it. Its gigantism in the mountains overwhelms my heart. The amount of its biodiversity ignites my gaze. At the boundaries of the lithospheric plates, collisions frighten and eruptions kill. 
But we don‚Äôt appreciate it. It‚Äôs dying. The only one. We polluted its beauty with garbage and noxious gases and slowly but surely destroyed its fragile natural uniqueness that gave us moments of life on the timeline.  For centuries, we have stuck knives full of gunpowder in it and tortured to possess it.
And now, in order not to become one of the extinct fossil forms that define a particular geological period, there is an extraordinary need to regulate the use of land resources and human ambitions.
These thoughts defined my future professional scientific interest - geology.

skills: ['Design', 'Education', 'Curation', 'Concept Development', 'Graphic Design', 'Exhibition Design', 'Typography']
summary:
Catelijne van Middelkoop is Research Professor/Practor ‚ÄòMeaningful Creativity‚Äô at SintLucas, Design Fellow at the Faculty of Industrial Design Engineering (IDE) at Delft University of Technology (TU Delft), and Sustainable Partnerships Developer at the Willem de Kooning Academy (WdKA). 

Van Middelkoop is a former Full Professor (of Practice) and Chair of Visual Communication Design at TU Delft/IDE (2016-2022), an experience that contributed to the establishment of the Pictorial Research Lab.

Besides being active in (redesigning) design education, Van Middelkoop is co-founder and partner of Strange Attractors Design (2001), a trans-disciplinary research studio known for its experimental and nonconformist approach to critical design practices.

Her main research (through design) interests include the influence of emerging technologies on the adaptiveness of design (related) institutions, the role of human creativity in a predominantly digital age co-created with/dictated by machines, as well as speculative futures for art and design education.

Van Middelkoop is a Ph.D. candidate at the RUG. She has an MFA in 2D Design from Cranbrook Academy of Art, a Degree in Graphic & Typographic Design from The Royal Academy of Art/KABK and studied Art History and Archeology at The University of Amsterdam. 

As a strategic advisor she has been a member of several Advisory Committees of the Creative Industries Fund NL, board member of The Association of Dutch Designers (BNO), and ambassador for a new ‚Äòvision on design‚Äô (2023-2030) for the Municipality of Eindhoven.

summary:
A highly qualified and responsible post-graduate archaeologist with international experience.

I recently gained a PhD in Archaeology at the University of Groningen, in the Netherland. My research results meet all academic requirements and provides sufficient proof of the ability to conduct independent research. My main strengths is to combine professional experience, strong analytical skills and self-motivation. 

My professional and analytical skills are based on a deep knowledge of and the love for archaeological field methodologies and artefacts ranging from the Neolithic to the Middle Age in the Mediterranean and on rescue archaeological job experiences that require working under pressure, practical approach to problem solving and a drive to see things through to completion. My self-motivation is based on reliability, dependability and determination to get a job done striving for quality and making respectful working relationships at all levels. 

Due to my multi-year research and work experiences, where I collaborated with several international universities and companies, I developed skills for managing projects and cultural initiatives. The participation in international conferences widened my network and proved to me the importance of communication in disseminating scientific results and in capitalizing on the many possibilities of development that culture can offer within and outside of the academic sector.

I'm an archaeologist interested in the interactions between humans and animals in the past and present. I specialise in the Late Mesolithic-Early Neolithic, exploring how the transition to farming impacted human-animal relationships over time.

I am trained in zooarchaeology and stable isotope analysis. I also have extensive fieldwork experience in the Netherlands, Germany, Iraqi Kurdistan, Jordan, and the US. I'm passionate about public outreach.

name: Linda Vlassenrood
position 2: Independent curator, program manager and researcher on urban planning
skills: ['Curating', 'Art History', 'Writing', 'Urban Planning', 'Architecture', 'Museums', 'Art', 'Fundraising', 'China', 'Shenzhen', 'Program Management', 'Team Management', 'Strategic Thinking', 'History', 'Contemporary Art', 'Research', 'Museum Collections', 'Lecturing', 'Art Exhibitions', 'Urbanism']
summary:
Linda Vlassenrood is a programme manager and curator whose mission is to facilitate understanding and discussion of complex urban issues in stimulating ways. She organises multi-year and shorter programmes for cultural institutions, municipalities and commercial entities; these may comprise advice, research, publications, workshops, exhibitions, educational projects, lectures and/or discussions. She excels at defining a question and then putting together the most appropriate method or process for discussing, researching or designing solutions.

Her ambition is to involve a broader group than just insiders in the development of cities. Her approach is therefore interdisciplinary by definition. As a result, she is easily able to bring together different types of designers as well as officials, citizens, researchers and other experts in the Netherlands and elsewhere. She brings multiple strengths to her role as a programme manager and curator ‚Äì creativity, analytical and strategic insight, entrepreneurship, drive and energy. In recent years she has focused on data and the smart society and on the development and redevelopment of new cities, particularly in China.

She worked as a curator and then chief curator at the Netherlands Architecture Institute (NAI) from 2000 to 2011. The NAI was one of the world‚Äôs largest public cultural institutions devoted to architecture and urban planning. She curated the Dutch contribution to the International Architecture Exhibition in Venice in 2004. In 2011, she founded Studio Linda Vlassenrood. She has been a core team member at Stad-Forum, an independent research organisation that advises the city of Amsterdam on urban development, since 2019. As a result of her activities, she is in demand as a speaker in the Netherlands and abroad. She has authored and co-authored numerous publications.

summary:
Margriet van Eikema Hommes is an art historian specialized in historical painting techniques and Dutch 17th and 18th century interior paintings. She wrote her PhD dissertation on the discolouration of 15th-17th century oil paintings. She conducted research into Dutch painting ensembles, including those in the Oranjezaal in Huis ten Bosch. From 2011-2018, she supervised the interdisciplinary NWO Vidi project From Isolation to Coherences, that integrates technical, visual and historical studies of Dutch painting ensembles: fromisolationtocoherence.nl 
Margriet is senior researcher at the Cultural Heritage Laboratory of the Cultural Heritage Agency of the Netherlands (RCE).

skills: ['GIS analysis', 'Cartography', 'Digital Mapping', 'LiDAR', 'CAD', 'Measurement Systems', 'Trigonometry', 'History', 'Archaeology', 'GIS', 'Cultural Heritage', 'Teaching', 'Geography', 'Museums', 'Lecturing', 'Databases', 'Museum Collections', 'Research', 'Peplum movies', 'Anthropology']
summary:
At the VU University Amsterdam.  

1. Database and descriptive statictics. (Access)The course is an extensive introduction into the correct creation and use of structured data in a database environment. Students of Archaeology, Near Eastern Studies and Ancient History follow this course. Students of general history will have the opportunity to follow this course from 2011. Recommended books:  EA Abbott: Flatland, R Kaplan: The nothing that is.

2.  Ancient cartography. A map is not just a map, it is much more. Old maps are far more instructive than most people think. Students will learn the meaning and the intentions of maps as well as their projection systems. Recommended books: JP Snyder; Flattening the Earth.

3. Visual disclosure of scientific data part 1: Vectorizing your material.
Students of Archaeology, Near Eastern Studies and Ancient History learn how to vectorise your old drawings correctly and prepare them for scientific analysis. (Program: AutoCAD) It is imperative that they learn about basic trigonometry, so special attention is given to this subject. During the course and the test they are not allowed to use a calculator. This course is followed by students from all over Holland and exchange students from Italy. Recommended books:  S Gibilisco: Trigonometry demystified.

4. Visual disclosure of scientific data part 2: An introduction into the correct use of GIS.
Students of Archaeology, Near Eastern Studies and Ancient History will learn how to collect and prepare de different types of digital data for use in a GIS environment. Only then are they allowed to analyze it in GIS. No Book, only a reader which I wrote myself.

5. Correct use of measuring equipment at archeological sites.
In this course student will learn to operate dumpy levels, theodolites and total stations correctly.
All courses are open to students from other Universities. 
For more information please look at the digital Rosters of the university

Specialties: Vectorizing 

MBB
It has been a busy time MBB has vectorized al lot of old excavations from The Netherlands  for scientific research: Apeldoorn, Dorestad(Wijk bij Duurstede) settlement ongoing, all the cemeteries are finished(3000 drawings finished, 1500 to go), Valkenburg de Woerd, settlement  Wageningen cemetery, Voerendaal, villa, Wijchen, cemetery, Ede, supervising, Goedereede, settlement, Aardenburg ongoing, settlement. The applied method is becoming a standard for old excavations.

In the beginning of the nineties my interest went into sponsored magazine concepts. We succesfully published the magazine Merhaba Turkiya and created new ideas for short distance inflight movies and a new concept sponsored magazine for Suzuki in the Netherlands.

Being the first company discovering the rapidly growing well to do senior citizen market we  decided to pitch fully on the senior market aged from 55-75 years old with personal loans. In less than 4 years we where market leader in the senior loan market.In this period we closed for about ‚Ç¨ 10.000.000 personal loans.
Since 2005 we do fully pitch on morgages with the filosofy that we only want happy clients, happy clients bring you more clients. The best advertisement is a real testimonial. Word to mouth.  In this period most of the competitors wanted to make as much money as possible, a happy client was not heard about. We decided to offer no nonsense products and enhanced the filosofy you get what we promise. No advertising, no shouting around just word by mouth.
Since we do have low overhead costs we do not need to sell any nonsense products. Thats the key of todays succes

name: Johan Verspay
skills: ['Archeologie', 'Archaeology', 'Historical Archaeology', 'Landscape Archaeology', 'Public Archaeology', 'Cultural Heritage', 'Dutch', 'History']
summary:
I graduated in 2007 at the University of Amsterdam on my thesis on Rural Brabant during the Late Middle Ages and early Modern Period. This research continued to fascinate me. 

After that I started working at the AAC/Projectenbureau, the archaeological research office of the UvA. The close relations between research, education and the archaeological practice I found particular appealing. The opportunity I got to put the lessons learned to practice were especially valuable and resulted i.a. therein that I won the SIKB trophy for ‚ÄòBest Research Design Brief‚Äô.

When in 2011 the AAC/Projectenbureau passed into Diachron UvA bv, I saw opportunities to build a new business. As a senior KNA-archaeologist I have been working as a project manager for the Southern Netherlands. A lot of energy I got from the challenge to connect our services to the needs of our clients; to let archaeological research not only be of value to the scientific community, but also to provide added value beyond. The close cooperation with our customers I found very rewarding. That delivering customized solutions can provide new opportunities as well proved our research on the agricultural landscape of Veldhoven, for which I was awarded the ‚ÄòGrand Prize of the Dutch Field Archaeology‚Äô.

At the start of the 2015 it was time for a reorientation. I then started as a research associate at the UvA for a study on ‚ÄòVillage formation in the Middle Ages‚Äô, a project by the Cultural Heritage Agency. Somewhat sooner than planned, I also started working as a freelance researcher with my own company: Creative Archaeology. As such I support my clients in research on rural communities during the Late Middle Ages and early Modern Period. This research also forms the subject of my doctoral research which I recently started at the University of West Bohemia. This combination of project (field)work, synthesizing research and an in-depth study allows me to develop myself further along this theme in the coming period.

summary: (Wrapping up my PhD this year: Open to Postdocs!) With a background in both the sciences and humanities, I strive to integrate my extensive archaeological experience from research and commercial excavations into an interdisciplinary approach in my work. To actively contribute to the expanding field of archaeological science, I have dedicated the past several years to acquiring knowledge in material sciences and reinforcing my understanding of chemistry, physics, and geology. I have received training in various analytical methods, encompassing both invasive and non-invasive techniques, ranging from spectroscopy to compound analysis. Eventually, my focus shifted towards isotope research on archaeological materials. Currently, I maintain expertise in stable isotope and radiocarbon analysis, and I am engaged in establishing a high-resolution chronology for early animal husbandry in the Netherlands, utilizing Bayesian statistical analysis.

summary:
Hydrology has been one of my passions since childhood. As consultant and project leader I have over 15 years of experience in the Netherlands and abroad in the field of hydrogeology and well management. 

My main field of expertise is clogging and integrity of wells for drinking water, irrigation, geothermal energy storage, etc. Previous work experience and secondments with consultancy firms, research institutes, water utilities, water boards and government agencies help me to gain an understanding of what is necessary to bring projects to a successful end. The past years, I focus on delivering large multi-client studies. Jointly coming up with solutions and testing them in practice gives me energy. 

Country experience:
Cambodia, Ethiopia, Laos, Mozambique, Netherlands, South Africa, Swaziland, Thailand, USA, Viet Nam.
Youth exchange programme with theatre action group in India.

Favorite projects:
- Clogging of sub-irrigation schemes (2019-present)
- Microbial profiling of short circuit flow in drinking water wells (2015- present)
- Field Pilot: Horizontal Drilled Wells (2013-present)
- Field Pilot: Expanded diameter Gravel Well, EDGW (2015-present)
- Clogging of dewatering system at excavate building site with Silicagel (2015-2017)
- Permeation of Polyethylene drinking water pipelines with organic Micro Pollutants (2013-present)
- Potentials for Fresh water supply and flood prevention using ASR (2013-2014)
- Impacts of ground water management on conservation of archeology (2012). 
- Scenario study on Water Management strategies and Climate Change on Subsidence in Peat Soils, Utrecht (2011-2010)
- Field trial water quality impacts of composite drainage, Zeeland (2009 - 2012).
- Integrated Fire- and Water management Strategy for Tram Chim Wetland, Viet Nam (2003 -2006)
- Improving irrigation performance in Africa (2002-2004)
- Watersecurity in Transboundary Riverbasin Management between South Africa and Mozambique (2001) - bicycle tour to interview stakeholders

Development of hydrogeological tools:
- GRETA: python package to calculate the fate of Organic Micropollutant and pathogens in the subsoil (ongoing)
- HGC: python package for analysis of ground water quality samples, based on work of Stuijfzand, 2017. (ongoing)
- PHOENIX 1.0: An ArcGis based Regional Soil Subsidence Model for Peat Soils (2012)
- DG Dialog Groundwater : A groundwater module for an Assetmanamagent package of Municipalities (2011)

summary:
Hallo
You can find my work at f.i.Saatchi, Singulart, Artfinder and Artmajeur. And of course on my website www.geertlemmers.com.

Born in the Netherlands, Geert Lemmers studied photography and photographic Art and worked as a freelancer for magazines and fashion artists before focusing on his artistic career in 2008, winning the same year the professional art-prize in his region.
My ideas and statements about ART: 
I think that art gives us back to ourselves in a renewed state. 
By paying attention to art for a moment, we tap into a source within ourselves and we gain access to the imagination. 
Art offers us new perspectives, makes us think and activates our senses. Art gives us value so that we feel we can be different from what we tend to think. 
She teaches us how we can free ourselves from our regular pattern, rise above ourselves and open ourselves to other people, to the world. 

¬´ Composing artworks for me almost is a philosophic question in transferring my thoughts into metaphorical representations. ¬ª 
Geert Lemmers is a prizewinning artist from the Netherlands whose works have been featured in shows internationally. Working across painting, photography and new media, Lemmers is inspired by philosophical questions and creates digitally altered images and abstract paintings that reveal hidden worlds. His work is characterized by enlarged characters in chaos, beauty, and imperfection.

summary:
Graduated as an archaeologist, I quickly realized that my curiosity and forte lies in telling stories about the unknown. How do we make difficult and ‚Äòdusty‚Äô topics like archaeology and science engaging and tangible for bigger audiences? In order to do that, we have to find the underlying story and urgency of the project, and communicate it in such a way that it touches and inspires. 

My love for storytelling and creating narratives, has led me to work in public archaeology and as a researcher and script writer for National Geographic Channel. Currently, I‚Äôm a content strategist for NorthernLight, a creative Amsterdam-based agency that creates transformative experiences for brands, museums and public spaces. Experiences that open up minds and widen perspectives. I‚Äôm proud to say that NorthernLight has done over 200 projects in 30 different countries.

Being a good listener, I‚Äôm sincerely interested in how people think and what motivates them. I have an endless fascination for the deeper meaning behind someone's action and words - I believe all it takes to get there, is asking the right questions.

name: Gene Shev
degree 2: Research Masters Archaeology: Religion and Society in Native American Cultures
skills: ['Anthropology', 'Climate Change Adaptation', 'Animal Husbandry', 'Zooarchaeology', 'Prehistoric Archaeology', 'Stable Isotope Analysis', 'Research', 'Microsoft Office', 'Microsoft Excel', 'Microsoft Word', 'PowerPoint', 'Photoshop', 'Teamwork', 'Public Speaking', 'Customer Service', 'Archaeological Survey', 'Public Archaeology', 'Excavation']
summary:
I am a postdoctoral researcher as part of the CaribTRAILS research project at  KITLV/Royal Netherlands Institute of Southeast Asian and Caribbean Studies. 

As an archaeological scientist I employ zooarchaeological methodologies and isotope ratio analyses to investigate pre-1492 Indigenous human-animal relations in the Caribbean region. Currently my research is focused on archaeological sites in the Dominican Republic, but also in the Dutch-speaking Caribbean islands of Aruba and Saba.

My interests lie in niche construction theory relating to human impacts on the environment and the effects these have on animals, understanding processes of domestication and sustainable animal management practices in Amerindian societies, and assessing human and animal responses to environmental degradation, overexploitation, and climate change.  My current research involves reconstructing past climates using isotopic analysis of faunal remains and assessing human responses to climate change in regard to the changing patterns of foodways and resource exploitation.

name: Joos 'Does' van Barneveld
skills: ['Graphic Design', 'Fine Art', 'Management', 'Social Media', 'Contemporary Art', 'Illustration', 'Painting', 'Art Direction', 'Marketing', 'Urban Contemporary Art', 'Graffiti', 'Street Art', 'Drawing', 'Murals']
summary:
‚ÄòHe who does creates‚Äô

Joos van Barneveld, better known as DOES, was born in Veghel, The Netherlands, in 1982. His prime passion was football and he trained and played as a professional player for football club Fortuna Sittard from the age of 9. In 1997 he discovered graffiti, a passion that coerced him into a double life. For more than a decade he was forced to combine the daily needs of a professional athlete with the night-time secrets of a graffiti writer. In 2010 a knee injury forced him to give up his career as a football player and rethink his future.
 
Where many would have experienced a drama, DOES saw the possibility to exclusively devote himself to art, developing his practice and carrying his craftsmanship to a higher level with the same dedication, focus and self-restraint that soccer taught him. Through the years, both as an artist and as a member of the LoveLetters graffiti collective, his style, which is today highly recognizable, has become a mix of influences from old-school writers and his own research. In his drawings and paintings you can discover the roots of 3D lettering, but you can also be surprised by his patient research of well balanced color schemes and his capacity of controlling the purity of outlines. As Phase 2 wrote in his Style Writing from the Underground manifesto in 1996: ‚ÄúWriting is centered on names, words and letters. Combined with the objective of their execution, this creates the product and the overall make up of the writer‚Äù. DOES perfectly understood this process and calmly researched his own style, which can be seen as a kind of controlled dripping. His letters, with their dizzying colour schemes, are stretched so much that they seem to release their energy and spread drips all over the wall.
 
While many recognize him as an ultra-talented draftsman and an amazing colourist, DOES is today moving the boundaries of his own artistic research in new conceptual directions, looking at graffiti as an archive from which he can physically pull out samples that embody his own roots. He drills or peels off walls covered with spray paint to include these artefacts into sculptures made of plaster. He develops a kind of contemporary archeology of urban spaces, keeping a trace of the geographical coordinates of these walls, readapting the tools of a science that normally deals with past times to underline his own story and the impact of graffiti culture on our society.

www.digitaldoes.com

This profound interest in the History of Mankind, as a way to better understand and protect it in the future, has been the backbone of my academic path.

I strive to look for any opportunity to bring my openmindedness, curiosity, patience, quiet determination, languages, and good people-listening skills to the service of International Archeological Project teams in the Middle & Near East, as well as underwater excavations which I aim to specialize in.

skills: ['Museums', 'Art History', 'History of Art', 'management of collections', 'Museum Collections', 'Curating', 'Cultural Heritage', 'Cultural History', 'Museum Studies', 'Publications', 'Writing', 'Museum Skills', 'Exhibition Management', 'Museum Education', 'auctions art and antiques', '(antiquarian) books and titels on the arts, arthistory and related fields', 'vrijwilligerswerk in museale sector en in de sector welzijn', 'research', 'reizen als lifter']
summary:
Ik ben een gedreven museumman die via collectiemanagement collecties op een hoger plan weet te tillen. Ik heb ervaring in het realiseren van tentoonstellingen met een goede balans tussen woord, beeld en geluid en sta borg voor een optimaal collectie- en depotbeheer. Projectco√∂rdinatie en budgettering zijn sterk aanwezige competenties. Ik ben betrokken, oprecht en loyaal en door analytische vaardigheden en creativiteit snel van toegevoegde waarde. Ik ken de klappen van de zweep en weet door jarenlange ervaring hoe processen lopen en wat wel en niet werkt of haalbaar is. Met partners ga ik graag verbindingen aan.

Ik ben beschikbaar voor:
- museale projecten
- tentoonstellingsprojecten (inhoudelijk en vormgeving)
- collectiemanagement (o.a. werving en afstoting vlg. LAMO)
- depotbeheer
- erfgoedprojecten en erfgoedspecialisatie
- museuminrichting
- inventarisatie
- collectieregistratie (Adlib)
- beheer en behoud
- rondleidingen
- onderzoek en documentatie
- kunsthistorische en culturele projecten
- trajectbegeleiding bij herbestemming roerend religieus erfgoed uit kerken en kloosters
- advies inzake kunst en antiek
- overname werkzaamheden boekhandel en antiquariaat
 
Nu 'ontzamelen' het museale sleutelwoord lijkt te zijn geworden verdient de herbestemming van verweesd religieus erfgoed alle zorg. Met kloostercollecties en roerend kerkelijk erfgoed heb ik een ruime ervaring. Bij eventuele herbestemming weet ik de juiste wegen en mogelijkheden.

Ik zoek daarnaast een ruimtelijk onderkomen in een aantrekkelijke ambiance voor het beheren, documenteren en tentoonstellen van religieuze kunst en volksdevotie, afkomstig uit de (zuidelijke) Nederlanden en aangrenzende invloedsgebieden. Deze collectie biedt perspectieven en aanknopingspunten voor diverse thematische tentoonstellingen.

summary:
Storytelling is the word that best encompasses my professional experience and personal passions. It has evolved and taken multiple forms throughout the years, as it applied to so many topics and fields.

Currently, I am a children‚Äôs book author and independent publisher. I recently self-published my first book, "The ABCs of Amsterdam: a first guide to the capital of the Netherlands", an alphabet travel guide of Amsterdam for young readers.

How did I get here?

Over the years, I contributed to creating over 40 museum exhibitions in internationally-renowned museums across the United States (especially the Field Museum in Chicago, IL), gaining extensive experience crafting compelling stories for different audiences and on many a different topics as well as managing large teams of most talented people.

After a family relocation to Amsterdam, I experienced again (after my relocation from my hometown in Italy to Chicago) that the more you know about a place, the more you feel at home. Same for children. 

So was born "The ABCs of Amsterdam", the first of the City ABC Books, a series that will take young readers around the world one letter at a time!

summary:
Graduated Research Master in Religious Studies with excellent study results, now working as a PhD candidate studying the ritualization of megalithic structures (hunebedden) in the Netherlands. During my MA, I specialized in the collective remembrance of conflicts, resulting in my Thesis on the collective memories on different aspects of the Dutch colonial period, as well as the fall of Srebrenica, and how these memories are created and shaped by the wording and images used in history textbooks. 

My education has given me the opportunity to conduct research on a broad range of topics, from archival research on collectors of non-Western art in the 1970's to the use of precolonial heritage in peace museums in Kenya, and from tiled walls in Catholic churches to the roles played by Mennonites in WWII. The one thing in common: all of these subjects deal with how history is 'created' in one way or another. Often the stories and created histories are at least as important as what actually happened in history, at least when looking at society. 

Apart from my research qualifications, I also have experience in organizing events, coordinating small teams of volunteers, and presenting for/entertaining children and young adults.

name: Sebastiaan van der Gaag
degree 2: Bachelor of Arts (B.A.) Archeologie & Prehistorie, UvA
skills: ['Meshlab', 'Agisoft Photoscan', 'Blender', 'ArcGIS', 'QGIS', '3D Studio Max', 'Cinema 4D']
summary:
I recently finished my studies as MA ‚ÄúArchaeology Theory & Practice‚Äù at Lund University. Over the span of my Bachelors at the University of Amsterdam my interest in Digital Archaeology grew. In pursuit of this I followed electives in Geographic Information Systems (GIS), and digital 3D modelling at the 4D research Lab. My BA thesis consisted of the development of a cumulative viewshed analysis within GIS. My ambition for further development and gathering of these skillsets brought me to Sweden were I followed a two year Master program. Within this program I was further taught in the use of GIS and 3D modelling tools, worked with different kind of laser scanners, satellite data and frequently with image-based modelling. A combination of (most of) the above mentioned techniques and methods form the foundation of my MA thesis, in which I researched how to increase the transparency of conduct of digital archaeological 3D reconstructions within the boundaries of a 3D GIS environment.

My passion lies foremost in 3D modelling, making reconstruction within the framework of cultural heritage and (building) archaeology and discovering/researching ways to communicate the underlying process to peers and the public.

degree 2: Post graduate certificate  in Advising for language learning
skills: ['Teaching', 'English', 'Higher Education', 'Curriculum Design', 'Intercultural Communication', 'Qualitative Research', 'Staff Development', 'Dutch', 'Teacher Training', 'Research Design', 'Lecturing']
summary:
Originally I am from the ‚ÄòStates, specifically from Michigan, but I came to Amsterdam as a student in the ‚Äò70s and never seriously considered moving back for good. I met my husband at the introductory lecture of our professor.  In Amsterdam I studied South and Southeast Asian history and archeology focusing on the Khmer Empire. The study I completed was in both Ancient and modern history of SEAsia from the University of Leiden.
There was no work in the ‚Äò80s for an inexperienced archeologist, so I decided to train as an EFL teacher of adults, getting an RSA- TEFL diploma in 1985.  Through the eighties and nineties we travelled and worked in various countries including a stint in the PRC (just after Tianamien) teaching future teachers of English at a ‚Äòthird rate‚Äô teachers‚Äô college in Xian. Also I worked at the language centre of a university in Hong Kong and as lecturer of academic writing in a small university in the north of Lebanon.
Teaching adults of all professions from Cape Verdean sailors in Rotterdam to Deutsche Bank staff in Dusseldorf ensured that I was flexible both in teaching an in design of learning trajectories in non-academic settings. Somewhere in all this time, I started doing a Masters in Adult Education from the OUUK while working full time. This was triggered by a growing fascination with the various ways that people learn.
More and more I wanted to understand how to design and deliver learning opportunities for adults. This was the core aim of research carried out in the later years of my working life.
Since retiring as a teacher/lecturer of mostly academic English at polytechs in the North of the Netherlands my husband, Lucas, and I have settled in a quite village in the extreme southeast of the country in Limburg.

name: ruud Koster
summary:
My medical and scientific career started in 1977 when I became a cardiologist in the Wilhelmina Gasthuis in Amsterdam. Between 1979 and 1981 I worked in the cardiology department in the Binnen Gasthuis. In June 1981 we moved to the new Academic Medical Center. I worked there at the department of Cardiology, where I fulfilled many different roles, from chief of the Coronary Care Unit,chief of the Emergency Cardiac Care unit,  chief of the Catheterization laboratory and supervisor of the consultation service. I followed training and practiced intervention cardiology and implantation of cardiac devices (pacemakers and implantable cardioverter-defibrillators, ICD's).
At the same time my research focussed on emergency cardiac care: prevention of ventricular fibrillation by anti arrhythmic drugs (the subject of my PhD thesis). After that my research centered on management of out-of-hospital cardiac arrest (OHCA). A registry started in 1995 which has recorded and analyses OHCA on an intense and uninterrupted basis since 2005: the ARREST (AmsteRdam REsuscitation STudies) study. A large intervention study of benefit of automated external defibrillators (AED's) was performed between 2000 and 2002. Ever since, I promoted and followed the introduction of AEDs, which was very successful. Introduction first was with police and fire fighters first responders, since 2009 also intensely in residential communities.
Our research group continuously engages in new research projects on OHCA. In association with Hanno Tan MD, PhD as co-PI (who received funding from the EU Horizon 2020 program with the program Escape-NET) and Marieke Blom, PhD as senior researcher there are now 7 PhD students and 5 data managers active in the ARREST group. 
I retired from the cardiology practice in 2014 but since then dedicate much of my time to the study of OHCA through the ARREST study, which I hope to continue several years to come.

name: Nico Bruining
position 1: Editor-In-Chief European Heart Journal - Digital Health
skills: ['Healthcare', 'Clinical Research', 'Medical Devices', 'Hospitals', 'Clinical Trials', 'Cardiology', 'Medicine', 'Medical Education', 'Medical Imaging']
summary:
Nico Bruining, PhD, FESC, began his career in 1985 at the Thoraxcenter (Department of Cardiology, Erasmus MC, Rotterdam, The Netherlands), working in the cathlab with pioneers in interventional cardiology, including Prof. P.W. Serruys and Prof. P.J. de Feyter. In 1993, he joined the Department of Experimental and Clinical Information Processing (KEI) at the Thoraxcenter, where he currently serves as the head of the department. Since mid-2020, he has also been the inaugural Editor-In-Chief (EiC) of the European Heart Journal ‚Äì Digital Health (EHJ DH).

With a degree in Technical Computer Sciences, Nico had a pioneering role in the development of three-dimensional (3D) echocardiography, which culminated in his 1998 PhD thesis, "Quantitative 3D Echocardiography of the Heart and the Coronary Vessels," under the supervision of Prof. J.R.T.C Roelandt. Since then, he has been evaluating new therapies within interventional cardiology using novel technologies, such as the first-in-man studies on drug-eluting stents and bioresorbable scaffolds using advanced coronary artery imaging with intracoronary imaging methods and computed tomography, by novel analysis methods with advanced computational methods. His current focus is on the broad field of Digital Health, which brings together clinical and technical innovations improving cardiovascular care developed in-house or in collaboration with industry. Some of his ongoing projects include general data registration, patient monitoring in-hospital and remotely, cardiovascular imaging, artificial intelligence, and seamless integration of computer-assisted analysis methods.

Nico is actively involved in international activities, in addition to serving as the EiC of the EHJ DH. He is the vice-chair of the ESC‚Äôs Digital Health Committee, the topic coordinator Digital Health for the congress program committee, and nucleus member of the CardioVascular Round Table. He previously chaired the ESC working group of Computers in Cardiology, and he also serves as the eCardiology editor of EuroIntervention and is the Specialty editor Digital Health for the European Heart Journal. Nico is a Fellow of the ESC and a member of the European Association of Cardiovascular Imaging (EACVI) and the European Association of Percutaneous Cardiovascular Interventions (EAPCI).

name: Michiel Rienstra
skills: ['Cardiology', 'Clinical Research', 'Genetics', 'Epidemiology', 'Electrophysiology', 'Heart Failure', 'Clinical Trials']
summary:
Clinical Summary
Graduated in medicine at the University of Antwerp, Belgium in 2003. Cardiologist since 2012, with focus on management of arrhythmias (atrial fibrillation) and heart failure. Clinical Director of the Department of Cardiology, University Medical Center Groningen, responsible for patient quality and safety. Chair of the Heart Center consisting of Department of Cardiology and Cardiothoracic Surgery. Initiator of HartNet, a regional network organisation of first, second and third line heartcare for inhabitants of the provinces of Groningen en Drenthe, supported by patient organisations and health care insurances. Involved in numerous institutional committes (Value-based Health Care program, Certification, Clinical capacity, member Stafconvent board, chair CdCs, etc.).

Research Summary
Obtained a PhD at the University of Groningen, The Netherlands in 2007 on Atrial Fibrillation, Underlying Disease and Prognosis. I completed my cardiology training at the University Medical Center Groningen in 2012, where continued working as clinical cardiologist and researcher. I was awarded with a NWO Rubicon grant in 2009 and went to Harvard Medical School, Massachusetts General Hospital and the Framingham Heart Study for a post-doc on population genetics and epidemiology in 2010-2011. In 2012 I was awarded with the NWO Veni grant for his project on genetics of atrial fibrillation. In 2015 I was awarded with the European Society of Cardiology academic grant for his project on a big data approach in atrial fibrillation. I am also part of several CVON consortia, and in steering cie of multiple investigator-initiatied trials on AF and/or HF. I am fellow of the European Society of Cardiology and the American Heart Association, and Leadership committee member of the Functional Genomics and Translational Biology council.

My clinical-oriented research consists of conducting clinical studies to improve AF treatment (RACE I to V, CONVERT, VIP-HF), studying epidemiology of AF and its risk factors in PREVEND, Lifelines and Framingham Heart Study, uncovering the genetics of atrial fibrillation in part with the CHARGE-AF/AFGen international consortium, and applying novel bioinformatics tools to improve AF risk prediction.

skills: ['Implementatieplannen', 'Communicatie', 'Klinische ontwikkeling', 'Business planning', 'Relaties opbouwen', 'Cardiology', 'Genetics', 'Heart Failure', 'Medicine', 'Science', 'Human Genetics', 'Molecular Biology', 'Research', 'Clinical Research', 'Medical Research', 'Cardiovascular Disease', 'Interventional Cardiology', 'Genetic Testing', 'Medical Education', 'Life Sciences']
summary:
I am head of the Department and interventional cardiologist. My clinical work includes the diagnosis and treatment of heart disease. In the cath lab I perform the percutaneous treatment of obstructive coronary artery disease, including the treatment of acute myocardial infarction and mechanical support in the setting of cardiogenic shock. 

My translational research focusses on the analysis of big and complex data (e.g. genetic, ehr, imaging), including the use of machine learning and cloud computing, to improve our understanding and the early detection of coronary artery disease and heart failure. To this end we use large population based cohorts, including the Dutch PREVEND and LifeLine cohorts and the UK Biobank. Data on my "omics" research can be found our my website: www.cardiomics.net and on www.ecgenetics.org
We also aim to bring big data analyses closer to individuals via the development of a Digital Twin (www.mydigitwin.nl)

In my clinical translational research I am also working on advanced image analysis, device interventions, machine learning, deep learning, e/mHealth, and patient centered outcome measures to further improve and personalize care for our patients. Currently ongoing diagnostic imaging studies in include the REPLACE-IT (replacement of invasive coronary angiography) and the EARLY-SYNERGY (early detection of obstructive coronary artery disease; www.early-synergy.nl) studies. Currently interventional studies include the GIPS-IV trial to be completed in 2021.

Many of my projects are based on collaborations with the most influential and creative individuals and research groups in the world.

More information can be found on;
www.hartwetenschap.nl

And my publications on pubmed;
www.pubmed.gov

See links below

name: Angela Maas
skills: ['Cardiology', 'Medicine', 'Medical Education', 'Clinical Research', 'Hospitals', 'Healthcare', 'Echocardiography', 'Medical Imaging', 'Medical Research', 'Internal Medicine', 'Healthcare Management', 'Clinical Trials', 'Epidemiology', 'Heart Failure', 'Public Health', 'Dutch', 'Cardiovascular Imaging', 'English', 'Pharmaceutical Industry', 'Lid Raad van Toezicht Saxenburghgroup Coevorden/Hardenberg']
summary: Angela Maas is a cardiologist since 1988. Over the past 30 years she has specialized in heart disease in women. In May 2012 she was appointed as professor in ‚ÄòCardiology for Women‚Äô at the Radboud University in Nijmegen, the Netherlands. The main focus of her work are cardiac symptoms in women at middle-age and the role of female-specific risk factors in (early) heart disease. In the past years she started an expertcenter for microvascular coronary disease at the Radboudumc. In 2015 she initated the Dutch SCAD registry (coronary dissections) and developed the theme cardio-oncology for women treated for breast cancer.  She enjoys working with other disciplines such as gynecologists, oncologists, epidemiologists , other vascular disciplines and primary care. Her aim is to widely implement a more gendersensitive cardiology care and to make the cardiology world friendlier for women. In 2014 she initiated the Radboudumc fund Heart for Women (www.hartvoorvrouwen.nl) to collect funding for innovative projects in cardiology care for women. She has been awarded by the Dutch society of female physicians (2010), Libelle Magazine (2010), the Radboudumc(2014), ‚ÄòVrouwenvanNu‚Äô (2015) and was knighted to Officer of Oranje Nassau in 2017. She is listed as one of the most powerful women in Dutch healthcare (Opzij 2011-2018) and was elected as number one in 2019. She is a former board member of the Dutch Society of female professors (2014-2019) and the supervisory board of the Saxenburghgroep in Hardenberg (2015-2020). Since September 2020 she is member of the supervisory board of the FlevoHospital in Almere. She was the 2020/21 elected representative of the Dutch Women‚Äôs  Council to the United Nations. Angela acts as a role model for younger colleagues. From May 2022 onwards she focuses on advisory and scientific work. Her contacts in business should aim to improve health and leadership positions in women, locally and overseas. She considers the combined interaction with art, different cultures and education very inspiring.

summary:
Tobias Bruning, MD, PhD, is a board certified Cardiologist specialized in Advanced Cardiac Imaging and Artificial Intelligence (AI) in health-care.

At present, he is member of the eHealth & AI Taskforce of the Dutch Society of Cardiology, and of the AI & eHealth Taskforce of the Dutch Association of Medical Specialists (FMS).

In 1994 he obtained his PhD in Clinical Pharmacology (cum laude), and has actively been involved in clinical trials as principal investigator during his time in the Maasstad Hospital. He has initiated several research projects in collaboration with the Erasmus Medical Center and the Technical University of Delft, amongst which an out-patient cardiovascular prevention project for Hindustani in the Rotterdam area (grant-fund 400.000 euro) and the development of a ‚ÄúSmart (AI) Stethoscope‚Äù.

At the Maasstad Hospital he has been member of the Regional Medical Ethical Committee and Management Board-member of the Medical Staff.

He introduced CT coronary angiography (CCTA) at the Maasstad Hospital in 2007, thus being the first non-academic hospital in The Netherlands to put CCTA to clinical use. Subsequently, he implemented fractional-flow reserve analysis of CCTA (FFR-CT, HeartFlow Inc.) at the Maasstad Hospital in 2017 being the first on the mainland of Europe to involve FFR-CT in daily practice.

From 2013 ‚Äì 2021 he was (co-)Chair of the residency program for cardiology at the Maasstad Hospital in collaboration with the Erasmus Medical Center.

He is specialized in artificial intelligence in healthcare (Stanford Online Certified) with focus on the development and successful deployment of AI solutions in Health Care. He recently founded Same Page Intelligence Consulting and acts as consultant for HeartFlow Inc.

name: Sing-Chien Yap
skills: ['Medicine', 'Medical Education', 'Clinical Research', 'Cardiology', 'Arrhythmias', 'Adult Congenital Heart Disease', 'Cardiac Electrophysiology', 'Pacemakers', 'Echocardiography', 'Cardiac Rhythm Management', 'Medical Research', 'Epidemiology', 'Catheters', 'Interventional Cardiology', 'Internal Medicine', 'Emergency Medicine', 'ICU', 'Healthcare', 'Hospitals']
summary:
Sing-Chien Yap, MD, PhD, FESC, FEHRA, is the medical director of Cardiac Electrophysiology at the Erasmus MC, University Medical Center Rotterdam (NL). He performs the full spectrum of EP, including complex catheter ablations, CIED implantations and lead extractions. In addition, he is responsible for the care of patients with genetic cardiac rhythm disease as part of an official recognized Center of Expertise. He is an enthusiastic clinical researcher and has (co)authored >130 scientific publications (H-index Web of Science 24). His research interests are clinical evaluation of novel EP technology and risk stratification for sudden cardiac death.

Dr. Yap completed the 2-year Clinical EP Fellowship program at the Erasmus MC and finished a 1-year post-doc Research Fellowship at the Division of Cardiac Electrophysiology at the Toronto General Hospital (Canada). He is a board member of the Netherlands Heart Rhythm Association (NHRA). He is honored to be a Fellow of the European Society of Cardiology (FESC) and European Heart Rhythm Association (FEHRA).

summary:
Pieter Kappetein, MD, PhD, is a Consultant Cardiothoracic Surgeon, Professor and Chair of the residency program at the Thoraxcenter at the Erasmus Medical Center in Rotterdam, The Netherlands. He is board certified in Cardiothoracic Surgery. 

He is Secretary General of the European Association for Cardio-thoracic Surgery, Secretary of CTSnet and chairman of the International Cooperation committee of the Society of Thoracic Surgeons in the United States.  

A decade of expertise in clinical trials and post-market studies with a focus on device products such as drug-eluting stents, heart valves and pharmaceutical products in cardiology and cardiac surgery.
Experience in interactions with regulators including FDA for CE-mark and PMA submissions.

He is Associate Director of the TCT conference, the largest Interventional cardiology meeting in the Unites States and program committee member of EuroPCR. Besides this he is member of the Editorial Board of the Annals of Thoracic Surgery and Deputy Editor of Eurointervention. 

His clinical interests include aortic valve surgery, indications, outcome; percutaneous valve replacement and repair; coronary surgery; outcome compared to DES; lung surgery and new techniques in the field; education; and epidemiology. He is co-principal investigator of the SYNTAX and EXCEL trial (comparing coronary surgery with drug eluting stents) and member and co-PI of the steering committee of the Partner EU trial and SURTAVI trial on percutaneous valves and the RESHAPE trial:  the evaluation of the Mitraclip in patients with heart failure.

He is also member of the steering committee of the Re-align trial on Dabigatran in patients with mechanical heart valves. His current research efforts are focused on the evaluation of new surgical techniques and the comparison of new techniques in cardiothoracic surgery with new techniques in interventional cardiology.

skills: ['Clinical Research', 'Cardiovascular Disease', 'Medical Education', 'Public Health', 'Hospitals', 'Cardiology', 'Epidemiology', 'Medicine', 'Healthcare', 'Medical Research', 'Life Sciences', 'Clinical Trials', 'Research', 'Internal Medicine', 'Medical Imaging', 'Healthcare Management', 'Cardiovascular diseases']
summary:
MAARTEN LAURENS SIMOONS, is Professor of Cardiology (emeritus) and was Chief of Cardiology, at the Thoraxcenter, Erasmus University Medical Center Rotterdam, The Netherlands. He is a fellow of the KNAW (Royal Netherlands Academy of Science and Arts), the Royal College of Physicians (London), the European Society of Cardiology and several other learned societies.
He was appointed Professor of intensive cardiac care at Erasmus University  (1990), and subsequently Professor of Cardiology (1998) and Chief of Cardiology, Chairman of the Thoraxcenter and Chairman of COEUR (cardiovascular research school at Erasmus University Rotterdam) in 2003. This position he held until his retirement in 2011.
Research interests: ischemic heart disease, coronary care, information technology, pharmacogenetics. He is a leader of many national and international clinical trials, related to acute coronary syndromes (reperfusion therapy, anti-thrombotic therapy, risk assessment) and stable coronary artery disease, including the GUSTO trials, CAPTURE, EUROPA, EXPEDITION, MAAS, PENTUA and PURSUIT. Currently he is member (chairman) of several Data Safety Monitoring Committees of international multicentre trials as well as the DSMC of Erasmus University Medical Centre and Leiden University Medical Centre.

Professor Simoons has been supervisor of 35 young scientists completing their PhD-thesis, and is the author or co-author of  > 600 publications in peer reviewed journals. See PubMed.
He was a member of the Board of the European Society of Cardiology from 1991 until 2004 and president of the Society 2000 - 2002. Furthermore he served on the board of the Interuniversity Cardiology Institute in the Netherlands (ICIN, 2003 - 2012).
From 2006 until 2013 he served as chairman of the scientific advisory board of the Netherlands Heart Foundation. 
He received the Snellen medal of the Netherlands Heart Foundation (2014)
In 2010 he was honoured as Ridder in de Orde van de Nederlandse Leeuw.

summary:
Marijke Linschoten is a PhD candidate at the Amsterdam Heart Center located at Amsterdam University Medical Center (Amsterdam UMC). She has a bachelor in Biomedical Sciences and was thereafter trained as a clinician and clinical researcher during the 4-year master program Selective Utrecht Medical Master (SUMMA). Currently she is enrolled in the Postgraduate Epidemiology Master program at Utrecht University.

Her research focuses on the impact of cancer treatment on the cardiovascular system within the field of cardio-oncology. This is a new emerging discipline that aims to find a balance between the optimal oncologic efficacy and reducing adverse cardiovascular effects of anticancer treatment. Since the COVID-19 pandemic she expanded her research to unravel the interaction between COVID-19 and the cardiovascular system. 

Marijke Linschoten (co-) founded several consortia including ANTICIPATE (https://www.kwf.nl/onderzoek/onderzoeksdatabase/voorkomen-van-hartschade-door-anthracyclines-in-patienten-met), CAPACITY-COVID (https://capacity-covid.eu) and DEFENCE (https://projecten.zonmw.nl/nl/project/defence-determination-and-evaluation-frequency-and-effects-myocardial-damage-patients-sars).

name: Pieter G. Postema, MD, PhD
skills: ['Clinical Research', 'Cardiology', 'Electrophysiology', 'Healthcare', 'Research', 'Medical Education', 'Genetics', 'Medicine', 'Hospitals', 'Medical Research', 'Cardiac Rhythm Management', 'Cardiovascular Disease', 'Surgery', 'Clinical Trials', 'ICU']
summary:
Dr. Postema is a certified cardiologist-electrophysiologist at the Heart Center @Amsterdam University Medical Centers, The Netherlands. He received both his propaedeutic and medical degree cum laude at the Free University in Amsterdam and his philosopher‚Äôs degree cum laude at the University of Amsterdam. During training he performed research at the Department of Cardiology and the Rayne Institute at Guy‚Äôs, King‚Äôs and St Thomas‚Äô School of Medicine, King‚Äôs College London, UK.

Dr. Postema is involved in the three academic pillars: patient care, medical education and research.

His patient care particularly encompasses patients with arrhythmia, pacemakers or implantable defibrillators. This involves both atrial and ventricular ablation procedures and implantations of pacemakers, defibrillators and cardiac resynchronization therapy. He is also strongly involved in cardiogenetics and in innovative treatment modalities for recurrent ventricular arrhythmia, e.g. cardiac radioablation. He is certified by the Dutch Cardiac Society (NVVC) and European Society of Cardiology (ESC) as a cardiologist and by the European Heart Rhythm Association (EHRA) as an electrophysiology specialist (ECES) and cardiac device specialist (ECDS).

His medical education involves teaching cardiology, particularly electrocardiography and electrophysiology, to medical doctors, nurses, students, allied professionals, patients and their relatives, locally and internationally. The latter is exemplified by his involvement in the non-profit CardioNetworks Foundation devoted to improving free access to medical knowledge throughout the world. He also is the founder and director of BrugadaDrugs.org devoted to provide free worldwide access to knowledge on drug use in Brugada syndrome for medical professionals, patients and their relatives.

His pre-clinical and clinical research is based on two intertwined topics, 1) the diagnosis, pathophysiological mechanisms, and treatment of malignant cardiac arrhythmias both in inheritable and acquired cardiac disease, and 2) electrocardiography in inheritable and acquired cardiac disease and on the population level with special focus on age, sex and ethnicity. Both these subjects are investigated within strong international collaborations.

Amongst others, is Dr. Postema a member of the Scientific Advisory Group on Cardiovascular Issues of the European Medicines Agency (EMA), member of the European Reference Network for low prevalence complex diseases of the heart (ERN Guard-Heart) and editorial board member of multiple international cardiology journals.

name: Prof. Dr. Natasja M.S. de Groot
skills: ['Cardiology', 'Electrophysiology', 'Congenital Heart Disease', 'Cardiac Rhythm Management', 'Cardiac Electrophysiology', 'Cardiac Mapping', 'Classical Ballet', 'Klinisch onderzoek', 'Algemene geneeskunde', 'Gezondheidszorg', 'Ziekenhuizen', 'Medisch onderwijs', 'Medische apparatuur']
summary:
Prof. Dr. Natasja MS de Groot, FEHRA, works as a cardiologist-electrophysiologist at the Erasmus Medical Center in Rotterdam, the Netherlands. Her work focusses on catheter ablation of complex tachyarrhythmias, particularly in patients with congenital heart disease. 
She is appointed as full-time professor in the EMC and University of Technology Delft. She is also a Medical Delta Professor (EMC-TUD-LUMC) and is the chair of the interdisciplinary Medical Delta Cardiac Arrhythmia Lab.
She is director of the unit translational electrophysiology. She founded together with 1) cardiac surgeon Dr. Yannick Taverne the Lowlands Center for bioelectrical medicine and the Erasmus Center of Cardiac Morphology and Electrophysiology, 2) biologist Prof. Dr. Bianca Brundel, the Atrial Fibrillation Innovation Platform. 
Her research program was in 2018 rewarded with the prestigious VIDI-grant. She was trained in clinical electrophysiology at the Leiden University Medical Center under supervision of Prof. Dr. Schalij and in experimental electrophysiology at the Cardiovascular Research Institute Maastricht under supervision of Prof. Dr.  Allessie. The title of her thesis was ‚ÄòMapping and Ablation of Atrial TachyArrhythmias; from Signal to Substrate. She has been involved in writing various international guidelines of the ESC/EHRA/HRS.
EMC performs about 1000 ablation procedures and 300 CIED implantations/year; cathlabs are equipped with a variety of novel mapping and ablation technologies offering her an excellent environment to translate her research findings into daily clinical practice.
A few examples of her current positions:
